“Dinner Guest” is a single by British rapper and singer AJ Tracey, featuring fellow UK rapper MoStack. The track arrived on 29 April 2020 and later served as the lead single for AJ Tracey’s second studio album, *Flu Game*, which was released in 2021. In the UK, the song became one of Tracey’s bigger chart hits of the period, reaching the top five on the UK Singles Chart and remaining a consistent presence in the upper end of the rankings for several weeks.

A notable musical element of “Dinner Guest” is its use of an interpolation and sample connected to “Push the Feeling On” by Scottish house act Nightcrawlers. That recognisable melody underpins the chorus and ties the song’s rap verses to a dance-oriented hook, a crossover approach frequently heard in UK rap and pop-rap releases around that time. The sample also appeared in other contemporary tracks, reflecting how older club records are often recycled to create familiar, crowd-friendly refrains.

The song was written and put together in early 2020, with AJ Tracey involved in the creative direction and production alongside The Elements. Its release also intersected with the first months of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom. In response to the developing public health crisis, Tracey stated that proceeds from first-week downloads would be donated to the COVID-19 Urgent Appeal to help support NHS workers and volunteers. The announcement followed his participation in the BBC Radio 1 charity cover “Times Like These,” another high-profile fundraising effort that reached number one.

On the charts, “Dinner Guest” entered the UK top ten in its opening week and held positions around the lower end of the top ten before climbing higher, eventually hitting its peak at number five in late June 2020.

The 2013 local elections in New Zealand were the nationwide round of votes held every three years to choose representatives for local government. Voters selected mayors, councillors, and community board members, and also elected people to serve on District Health Boards and certain other local organisations such as Licensing Trusts. Voting was carried out by mail, with the official election day falling on Saturday 12 October 2013.

Most councils used the first-past-the-post method, where the candidates with the highest totals win the available positions. A smaller number of councils used the single transferable vote system, which allows voters to rank candidates in order of preference and can produce more proportional outcomes. In 2013, STV was used by the city and district councils in Dunedin, Kapiti Coast, Marlborough, Palmerston North, Porirua, and Wellington. Among regional councils, the Wellington Regional Council was the only one to apply STV. District Health Board elections, by contrast, were conducted using STV across the country.

Not every area held elections that year. Environment Canterbury and Kaipara District were being run under statutory management arrangements, so the usual local authority elections did not take place there.

The timing of the elections was set by legislation. The Local Electoral Act 2001 requires a general election for members of local authorities and community boards on the second Saturday of October every third year, which set the date in 2013. The Electoral Commission published a schedule of key steps leading up to polling, including nomination periods and the mailing and return of ballot papers.

There was discussion about whether other votes might be held alongside the local elections, but a separate referendum was ultimately conducted later in the year using its own postal voting period.

*Bahamut* is the first full-length release by the American ensemble Hazmat Modine, a group known for blending blues and folk traditions with jazz and global influences. Issued on August 26, 2006 through Barbès Records, the album presents a mix of original compositions and reworked traditional material. Much of the writing comes from the band’s frontman, Wade Schuman, while several pieces draw on older songs that the group reshapes through distinctive arrangements and an unusual instrumental palette.

A notable feature of the record is the participation of the Tuvan group Huun-Huur-Tu on three selections. Their signature throat-singing adds a resonant, overtone-rich vocal texture that contrasts with and complements Hazmat Modine’s roots-based sound. The overall instrumentation is intentionally eclectic, incorporating brass and reeds alongside multiple guitars and less common instruments such as claviola and cimbalom. This combination allows the band to move between grooves and timbres associated with blues, klezmer, calypso, ska, and other styles without settling into a single genre identity.

The album achieved measurable commercial visibility within its niche, reaching number 12 on Billboard’s Top Blues Albums chart. Critical response was generally positive. AllMusic’s Jeff Tamarkin awarded it four out of five stars, emphasizing the group’s ability to merge disparate traditions into music that feels both familiar and unconventional. Pitchfork’s Joe Tangari also highlighted the collaboration “Everybody Loves You,” describing the project as an expansive, “roots” approach that remains striking in its final result.

Daniel “Dan” K. McAllister (born May 14, 1965 in Iqaluit, Nunavut) is a former territorial legislator and onetime operations supervisor in the northern retail sector. He entered public office after winning the 2005 territorial election in the Qikiqtaaluk South district, unseating a sitting representative in a close contest. During his first term, he sat on committees dealing with community services and government spending, and he was known locally for emphasizing practical improvements to housing and transportation.

Near the end of his mandate, McAllister became the subject of an ethics review related to residency and public allowances. In 2008, the territory’s integrity commissioner found that he had signed a declaration stating that his primary residence was in a smaller community within his district. That declaration made him eligible for a living allowance intended to cover the additional cost of maintaining accommodations in the capital while the assembly was in session. Investigators later concluded that he spent most of his time at an address in the capital and did not meet the residency standard required for the benefit. The ruling ordered repayment of a portion of the allowance and prompted stricter guidance on documentation for future claims.

McAllister ran again in the next general election but placed near the bottom of the results and did not return to the legislature.

Phoenix is the fifth studio release by the American vocal group Labelle, issued in 1975. While it did not become a major crossover blockbuster, it performed respectably, reaching the mid-range of the main pop album chart and landing in the top tier of the R&B listings. Promotion for the record produced a small-charting single, “Messin’ with My Mind,” authored by group member Nona Hendryx, who served as the album’s primary songwriter.

The record stands out in the trio’s catalog because it shifts stylistic emphasis compared with the funk-driven direction of the previous year’s Nightbirds. Phoenix leans more heavily into rock textures, using sharper guitar lines and a more aggressive band sound, while still retaining the group’s layered harmonies and soul phrasing. Several song titles and lyrical themes draw on celestial imagery, suggesting a loose concept built around transformation and motion.

Most of the tracks were composed by Hendryx, with selected pieces credited to additional writers. The album’s sequence includes “Phoenix (The Amazing Flight of a Lone Star),” “Slow Burn,” “Black Holes in the Sky,” “Good Intentions,” and the co-written “Far As We Felt Like Goin’.” The second half features “Messin’ with My Mind,” “Chances Go Round,” “Cosmic Dancer,” “Take the Night Off,” and “Action Time,” illustrating a mix of concise songs and longer, more exploratory arrangements.

Labelle’s core lineup—Patti LaBelle, Nona Hendryx, and Sarah Dash—handles the lead and group vocals. The backing musicians include guitars, bass, keyboards, drums, and percussion, augmented by a horn section and additional instrumental colors such as organ and electric piano. Production and arranging work helped connect the rock-leaning approach with the group’s established R&B foundations, making Phoenix a transitional project that documents Labelle experimenting with a broader sonic palette.

Rolf Ketterman (born 12 March 1962) is a retired Dutch cyclist who later worked as a team sporting director. He is best known for his achievements in cyclo-cross, including winning the men’s title at the 1990 UCI Cyclo-cross World Championships. Cycling was a family interest: his younger brother, Pieter, also raced at elite level for several seasons.

Ketterman grew up in a small town near Nijmegen and began his career on the road, where he developed endurance and bike-handling skills on narrow, winding courses. Although he collected a handful of notable results in one-day races, he gradually shifted his attention to cyclo-cross after finishing on the podium at the 1988 World Championships. That performance convinced him that the winter discipline suited him better, and he spent extended periods racing in Belgium and northern France, where the sport had the deepest fields and the most frequent events.

His breakthrough came at the 1990 Worlds, held on a demanding circuit featuring heavy grass sections, deep ruts, and a steep bank that riders had to crest repeatedly. Ketterman’s advantage was his ability to stay mounted longer than most competitors and accelerate immediately after the technical sections. By gaining a few seconds each lap at the same key obstacles, he built a decisive lead and secured the rainbow jersey.

After his world title, Ketterman became a regular contender in major series events and helped draw attention to cyclo-cross in the Netherlands, where the sport was still developing compared with Belgium. His later career was marked by occasional disputes around equipment rules and race incidents, though he avoided lengthy suspensions and continued competing at a high level through the early 1990s.

Following retirement, he moved into management, serving as a directeur sportif for several professional teams and guiding younger riders through the tactical and logistical demands of the cyclo-cross season.

Mezek is a small settlement in southeastern Bulgaria within the municipality of Svilengrad, Haskovo Province. The village is positioned where the eastern Rhodope foothills meet the lowlands, close to the national border with Greece and within easy reach of the Bulgarian–Turkish frontier. Because of this location, the area has long been influenced by trade routes and shifting political boundaries, which is reflected in the range of historical sites found nearby.

The best-known landmark is the medieval fortress above the village, often cited as one of the most intact defensive complexes from Bulgaria’s Middle Ages. Most scholars date its construction to the 11th century, when border fortifications were important for controlling passes and roads. The fortification is notable for its multiple towers and a layout designed to reinforce the most exposed sections of the walls. Built primarily from stone, its exterior includes decorative brick bands that add both strength and a distinct appearance. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, parts of the structure were damaged when building material was taken from the ruins for other construction projects in the region.

Mezek is also associated with Thracian heritage through two beehive-style tombs in the vicinity. The larger tomb, dated to the 4th century BCE, consists of a long covered entrance corridor leading to successive chambers and a circular burial room containing a stone sarcophagus. Archaeological research has indicated multiple high-status burials, and many recovered objects—metal ornaments, vessels, and other grave goods—are preserved in national museum collections.

Beyond archaeology, the village is recognized for local wine production, with vineyards benefiting from the warm borderland climate. For visitors interested in nature, a marked hiking route begins in the village and climbs toward nearby peaks, offering a longer walk suitable for a full-day outing.

Eulace Peacock (August 27, 1914 – December 13, 1996) was a prominent American track and field competitor whose best years came during the 1930s, a period when U.S. sprinting and jumping events drew growing national attention. He was born in Dothan, Alabama, and as a child moved to New Jersey, where he grew up in the Vauxhall area of Union Township. At Union High School he developed into an unusually versatile athlete, showing speed in short sprints as well as ability in the long jump. In 1933 he produced a record-setting jump that became one of the most durable marks in New Jersey scholastic history, remaining unmatched for decades. The same era also brought frequent comparisons to Jesse Owens, and the two met often in high-profile meets, creating a rivalry that helped elevate interest in amateur track.

After high school, Peacock enrolled at Temple University in Philadelphia. While in college he continued to compete at an elite level and joined Alpha Phi Alpha, reflecting both his athletic and campus involvement. He became especially known for his success in multi-event competition. Over the course of his career he won the Amateur Athletic Union outdoor pentathlon title six times, with victories spanning the mid-1930s and extending into the World War II years. His combination of sprinting speed and jumping skill made him dangerous in meets that rewarded all-around performance, and he occasionally defeated Owens in head-to-head races. A notable win in 1935 received wide coverage and reinforced the view that Peacock was among the strongest contenders in American track.

His trajectory toward the 1936 Olympic season was disrupted by injury. A hamstring problem prevented him from reaching the form needed to qualify for the Berlin Games, an outcome often cited as one of the major “what ifs” of that Olympic cycle. During the war years he served in the United States Coast Guard, and after his athletic prime he pursued business, including operating a liquor store and later a car-rental venture.

Peacock remained connected to the sport by working as an official at major meets, including national championships and Olympic trials. Over time, athletic organizations recognized his achievements, including induction into track and field halls of fame. He died in Yonkers, New York, at age 82 after living with Alzheimer’s disease, and was buried at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla.

Agnes “Nan” Paterson Hardie (5 October 1885 – 27 June 1947) was a Scottish activist associated with the labour movement and local government in Ayrshire. Born in the mining town of Cumnock, she grew up in a household where politics and working-class organisation were regular topics of conversation. Her father, Keir Hardie, was an influential trade union figure who later became a leading voice in the early Labour Party. He encouraged his daughter’s interest in public affairs, exposed her to debates within the movement, and helped her meet prominent reformers and organisers. These early contacts shaped her outlook and provided a network that remained important throughout her life.

Hardie’s formal education ended when she was fourteen, a common experience in working communities at the time. In her late teens she suffered a severe period of illness, including pleurisy and appendicitis. Although she recovered, her health remained fragile, affecting her stamina while not diminishing her commitment to public work. During the years before the First World War she often travelled with her father as he addressed meetings, including a trip to Nova Scotia in 1912. When his health deteriorated in 1915, she and her mother became his principal carers until his death later that year.

In 1924 she married Emrys Hughes, a socialist journalist and political organiser. For much of the following decade she supported his work, assisting with campaigns, correspondence, and local engagement. Her own public role expanded in 1933 when she won election to Cumnock Town Council. There she became closely involved with municipal services, notably through leadership in public health, where housing conditions and sanitation were central concerns.

By the mid-1930s she held the civic office of provost, and she and her husband pursued an ambitious programme to replace overcrowded and unhealthy housing with municipally built homes. The initiative transformed living conditions on a large scale and became a defining feature of the town’s interwar development. Alongside housing, she promoted recreation and welfare, with particular attention to opportunities for children, and encouraged accessible outdoor pursuits such as cycling.

Hardie also served as a magistrate and, during the Second World War, chaired a local war work organisation aimed at supporting service personnel and their families. Even while holding critical views about the conflict, she emphasised practical assistance and community welfare. In 1946 Hughes fell seriously ill, and the strain of caring responsibilities worsened her own condition. She died in June 1947.

Ion Grigorescu (12 February 1875 – 6 May 1946) was a Romanian scientist and public figure known for his work in chemistry and higher education. He became a full member of the Romanian Academy in the mid-1920s, recognition that reflected his influence on scientific training in the country. Grigorescu was born in a rural community near Iași, into a family shaped by local administration; his father, a village official, died when Ion was still a child, a loss that affected his early years but did not interrupt his studies.

After completing secondary school, he pursued university training in Romania and continued specialization abroad, returning with a strong interest in the emerging field of physical chemistry. At the University of Iași he taught for decades, introducing laboratory-based instruction and encouraging students to connect chemical theory with measurable phenomena. He is often associated with the publication of one of the earliest Romanian-language courses that systematically treated kinetic theory, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, and atomic structure.

Alongside academic work, Grigorescu participated in civic life and joined a major agrarian political movement of the interwar period. He later held municipal responsibilities in Iași, where he promoted public education and support for cultural institutions. His family life was extensive, and several descendants pursued careers in scholarship and the arts.

A clearance measuring vehicle is a specialized piece of railroad maintenance equipment used to verify the free space around a track. Railways must ensure that bridges, tunnels, platforms, signals, and other trackside structures leave enough room for trains that match the company’s approved loading limits. This safe space is often described as the route’s “clearance envelope,” accounting not only for a car’s static dimensions but also for sway, suspension movement, and track curvature.

By recording real-world clearances along a corridor, the railway can confirm that standard freight and passenger equipment can pass without contact. The same data is also valuable when planning shipments that exceed typical dimensions, such as transformers or industrial machinery. With accurate measurements, operators can judge whether an oversized load can travel a given route and identify the maximum practical height or width.

Early systems were relatively simple. Some railroads mounted a rigid frame shaped to the permitted profile on a flatcar; any strike against an obstruction indicated that the route no longer met requirements. More advanced designs introduced flexible “feelers” or whisker-like rods extending outward. When a rod brushed a structure, its movement could be recorded and translated into a clearance reading. Because the rods could bend and spring back, they reduced damage during minor contacts.

Modern clearance surveys increasingly rely on optical sensors. Laser scanners and other electronic instruments can map the surrounding space continuously while the vehicle moves, producing detailed digital profiles. These systems are often installed on self-propelled units, including road-rail vehicles that can operate both on highways and on tracks. The resulting measurements support safer operations, faster route qualification, and more confident planning for nonstandard shipments.

Riverside Park North is a neighbourhood green space in Ottawa, situated near the residential streets off Harkness Avenue. The park commemorates Pauline Vanier, a well-known community figure, and reflects the city’s postwar expansion of local recreation areas. It was created in the early 1960s on land that had previously been used for farming, and it sits close to a nearby public school, which has helped make it a common destination for families.

For many years, residents associated the park with seasonal community events. A long-running fireworks night was coordinated by the local community and recreation association and became a yearly tradition. Over time, updated safety rules and the need for more space led organizers to relocate the event to a larger venue. After several years without a display, the fireworks returned to the broader area when celebrations were later hosted at Mooney’s Bay.

The park includes standard amenities for children, such as swings and climbing equipment, along with an outdoor wading pool used during the summer. The City of Ottawa is responsible for operating the pool, providing supervision during open hours, and managing daily maintenance. The pool area is not enclosed; it is typically filled for daytime use and emptied at the end of the day.

A small field house supports park operations, serving as a staff base and storage space. Built as part of a citywide program in the late 1960s, it also becomes useful in winter when a boarded outdoor skating rink is set up nearby. Community volunteers help maintain the ice through the season. Baseball and t-ball diamonds round out the park’s sports facilities.

Tiffany D. Cross (born February 6, 1979) is an American journalist, television host, political commentator, and author. She is known for presenting MSNBC’s Saturday morning program *The Cross Connection*, where she discusses national politics and current events with a focus on culture, policy, and civic participation.

Cross was born in Ohio and spent much of her upbringing moving between Cleveland and Atlanta, experiences that later shaped her interest in how regional communities engage with news and public life. As a teenager, she became interested in television journalism and imagined a career that combined sharp political reporting with a strong on-air presence. She later enrolled at Clark Atlanta University, studying mass communications with coursework centered on broadcasting, including radio, television, and film.

Her career began in radio news in Atlanta, where she worked as a reporter and gained experience covering local stories and interviewing public figures. She later moved into television production and held positions at major media organizations, including work with CNN as an associate producer during the 2000s. Cross also took on leadership responsibilities as bureau chief in Washington, D.C. for BET Networks, a role that involved managing political coverage from the nation’s capital and coordinating reporting around elections and federal policy.

Alongside newsroom roles, Cross expanded her work into public speaking and analysis. She became affiliated with the Harvard Kennedy School’s Institute of Politics as a resident fellow, engaging with students and public forums on media, democracy, and political participation. She also appeared frequently on MSNBC programs, including *AM Joy*, where she provided commentary on breaking news and the political landscape.

In 2020, Cross published *Say It Louder: Black Voters, Our Voices, and the Shaping of American Democracy*, a book that examines the influence of Black voters in U.S. elections and the broader struggle for representation. Later that year, MSNBC selected her to lead a new weekend show, marking a significant step in her on-air hosting career and expanding her role within the network’s political programming.

The system of ranks and insignia used by the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation in the years after the Soviet Union’s collapse developed through a series of regulatory and design adjustments. When the Russian state inherited much of the former Soviet military structure, it also inherited an established visual language for identifying service branch, category of personnel, and seniority. Over time, that legacy was revised to reflect new legal frameworks, new uniforms, and a desire to standardize markings across the services.

One important shift concerned the highest grades. The post-Soviet regulations removed several Soviet-era senior marshal titles that had once existed for particular branches. As a result, the top of the hierarchy was simplified, leaving a smaller set of apex appointments and clearer distinctions between general and flag officers.

Rank insignia in this period relied heavily on shoulder boards, which served as the primary display area for symbols, stripes, and stars. The details varied by uniform type. Working and field uniforms tended to use subdued or simplified shoulder boards suited to camouflage and daily wear, while service and parade uniforms used brighter colors and more decorative elements, making rank and affiliation easy to recognize at formal events.

Enlisted personnel generally had minimal rank display on everyday clothing. On some uniforms, the shoulder board could carry a letter or emblem indicating affiliation rather than a detailed rank. Such markings helped distinguish broad categories—such as armed forces or naval personnel—and also identified students in military educational institutions. Cadets and school pupils could be marked by letters associated with their academy or training track, while naval trainees might use an anchor motif rather than a letter.

Non-commissioned officers used more explicit rank cues. Their shoulder boards combined branch identifiers with stripes that indicated progression through NCO grades. Color and finish depended on the uniform: field gear used muted tones, whereas service and ceremonial uniforms used brighter or metallic-looking trim. This made it possible to preserve readability without compromising practical considerations in the field.

Warrant officers and their naval equivalents occupied an intermediate category. Their shoulder boards often resembled those of enlisted and NCO personnel in overall shape and branch marking, but rank was shown by small stars set in a vertical pattern. This star arrangement provided a clear visual separation from both stripe-based NCO insignia and the larger star systems used for commissioned officers.

For commissioned officers, star size and the presence of decorative borders signaled status and level of command. Junior officers typically used simpler boards with basic ornamentation and smaller metal stars. Field-grade and staff officers used more elaborate layouts, including additional vertical elements and larger stars. The most senior appointments used richer embroidery, with prominent stars and, at the very top, state symbols such as the Russian coat of arms.

These conventions were later superseded by updated standards introduced by presidential decree in 2010, following a transition period that began with new uniform issues in the late 2000s. The result was a revised, legally defined insignia system intended to modernize appearance while maintaining continuity in how rank and role are displayed.

Castillo de San José is a coastal fortress in Arrecife, the capital of Lanzarote in Spain’s Canary Islands, and it is now best known for housing a museum devoted to modern and contemporary art. The building combines military architecture from the late eighteenth century with a later cultural role that reflects the island’s efforts to preserve heritage while expanding public access to the arts.

Construction took place between 1776 and 1779, during a period of severe hardship on Lanzarote. The island had suffered long-term damage from the Timanfaya volcanic eruptions earlier in the century, and repeated droughts further reduced agricultural output. In response to poverty and food shortages, the Spanish crown supported public works that could provide wages as well as infrastructure. The fortress therefore served two purposes: it offered employment to residents in crisis, and it strengthened defenses against maritime threats, including pirate raids that had been a recurring concern for Atlantic islands.

The fort occupies a strategic position above the Puerto de Naos area, looking out across the sea approaches to Arrecife. Its plan is adapted to coastal defense, with rounded seaward-facing walls designed to better withstand cannon fire and to widen the field of view. The landward side was more controlled, incorporating additional protective elements and a restricted entrance. Built from local stone, including volcanic materials, the structure contains a series of vaulted interior spaces that were suited to storage and military use, such as keeping supplies and ammunition under stable conditions.

In the second half of the twentieth century, the site underwent a major transformation. Rather than remaining a purely historic monument, it was refurbished to become an arts venue, with design interventions led by the Lanzarote-born artist and architect César Manrique. The museum that opened in the 1970s became known as the International Museum of Contemporary Art (MIAC). Its collection emphasizes art from the postwar decades, particularly works associated with abstraction and experimentation, including sculpture, kinetic pieces, and geometric or informal abstract painting. Spanish artists are especially prominent, and the museum also highlights creators connected to the Canary Islands.

The fort’s courtyard and surrounding areas are used for displaying works in open air, linking the art to the landscape and the building’s distinctive silhouette. An additional renovation created a restaurant within an adjoining section, connected internally and designed to take advantage of the sweeping views over the harbor, making the site both a cultural destination and a prominent landmark on Lanzarote’s coastline.

Monument Park is the outdoor walkway beyond center field at Yankee Stadium, the home of the New York Yankees. It functions as both a passageway for fans and a public tribute to the players, managers, and executives who shaped the franchise. Although it sits within a modern ballpark, the idea behind the space is rooted in an older tradition: the Yankees long maintained a dedicated area for plaques and retired numbers, treating the stadium itself as a museum of team history.

The park is arranged as a landscaped exhibit that can be viewed from the concourse. Along the perimeter are bronze plaques that summarize achievements and highlight key moments. Nearby, a row of large numbers marks the jerseys that the organization has taken out of circulation in honor of iconic figures. Together, the plaques and numbers help explain why certain names carry special weight, even for visitors who may not know the details of different eras of baseball.

Several monuments stand out for their scale and prominence, often dedicated to legendary Yankees such as Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, and Joe DiMaggio. These pieces are not simply decorative; they represent how baseball teams preserve collective memory in a way that resembles civic memorials. The names and dates provide an accessible timeline, while the surrounding design encourages fans to pause and read rather than simply pass by on the way to their seats.

Because the area is visible to the public, it also shapes the pregame routine. Fans frequently gather along the railings to take photos, point out familiar numbers, or compare the careers of different honorees. In this sense, Monument Park plays a role similar to a small exhibit hall: it offers context for what is happening on the field by emphasizing the continuity between past and present.

The location near center field is practical as well. It makes the tribute space easy to reach from multiple gates and places it close to concessions and other fan amenities. The result is a setting where history and entertainment sit side by side, reinforcing the idea that a baseball game is not only a competition, but also part of an ongoing story that the stadium is designed to tell.

Arba Minch Airport serves the city of Arba Minch in southern Ethiopia, within the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples’ Region. The city’s name is sometimes written in different Latin spellings, and the airport is commonly referred to by those variants as well. The airfield lies a short distance from the urban centre, positioned near the lakes that characterize the area, including Lake Abaya, making it an important access point for residents, officials, and visitors traveling to the Rift Valley region.

The airport is built on elevated terrain, which influences aircraft performance and operational planning. It has a single paved runway identified by the numbers 03 and 21, indicating its approximate compass headings. The runway surface is asphalt-based, suitable for regular domestic operations using small and medium-sized aircraft. Basic aviation infrastructure supports routine passenger handling and airfield services, allowing scheduled flights to connect Arba Minch with larger hubs in Ethiopia. As with many regional airports, the range of destinations can change depending on airline schedules, seasonal demand, and broader network planning.

Beyond civilian transport, the airport has also drawn attention for security-related activity. In the early 2010s, public reporting indicated that U.S. forces were using the location to support surveillance missions in the Horn of Africa, including reconnaissance flights associated with monitoring militant groups in Somalia. Statements attributed to U.S. military representatives described a limited footprint focused on operational and technical assistance, and emphasized cooperation dependent on approval from Ethiopian authorities. Reports also noted that investments were made to improve facilities for unmanned aircraft operations, while suggesting that missions were oriented toward intelligence collection rather than launching strikes from the airfield. Over time, the regional basing and deployment arrangements for such systems have shifted, with some related sites elsewhere being scaled down or closed.

Kolkata TV is a round-the-clock Bengali-language news broadcaster that began operations in 2006 under the umbrella of SST Media. The channel’s early formation is associated with journalist Suman Chattopadhyay, who had earlier worked with ABP and played a key role in shaping the station’s initial direction. Over time, the network came under the control of Kaustuv Ray, who is linked to the RP Group and has also served as the channel’s editor. Its on-air tagline, “Raatdin Saatdin,” conveys the idea of continuous news coverage throughout the week.

The channel is operated by RP Techvision (I) Pvt Ltd, based in Kolkata. In the public sphere, Kolkata TV has often been identified with an editorial posture that scrutinizes the Narendra Modi-led central government while appearing comparatively accommodating toward the Trinamool Congress (TMC), a major political force in West Bengal. Such perceptions have contributed to the channel’s distinct positioning within the state’s competitive regional media environment.

Kolkata TV and its owner have also drawn attention due to a series of legal and regulatory developments. Kaustuv Ray has faced investigative actions by central agencies, including Enforcement Directorate (ED) searches reported in 2018. He was later arrested by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) in connection with allegations related to bank fraud involving substantial sums. Reports also mention that he received further ED communication in 2021.

Around the same period, the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting issued a formal notice to the channel asking why its broadcasting authorization should not be withdrawn. The communication cited the Ministry of Home Affairs’ decision regarding security clearance as the basis for potential cancellation. Ray publicly argued that the measure was intended to curb critical journalism and intimidate outlets that challenge those in power.

The episode triggered political debate and drew statements of support for the channel from several opposition parties and prominent figures, including leaders from West Bengal and other states. In subsequent court proceedings, interim legal protections were reported, including directions limiting coercive action and judicial scrutiny of the government’s notice.

The 2021 Nottingham Trophy was a professional tennis event held on outdoor grass courts in Nottingham, United Kingdom. It formed part of two competitive circuits: the men’s tournament belonged to the ATP Challenger Tour, while the women’s tournament was included on the ITF Women’s World Tennis Tour. Matches were played over one week from 14 to 20 June 2021, serving as a lead-up opportunity for players preparing for the grass-court season.

As in most tournaments, the singles draws were built from several entry categories. Seeded players were determined by their world rankings from late May 2021. In addition to direct acceptances, a number of competitors entered through wildcards, which are invitations granted by the organizers, often to support local players or promising young athletes. On the men’s side, wildcards were given to Jay Clarke, Anton Matusevich, and Aidan McHugh. One player, Tomáš Macháč, was admitted using a protected ranking, a mechanism that helps athletes return to competition after a long injury absence.

Other places in the men’s main draw were filled by alternates, including Thomas Fabbiano, Leonardo Mayer, and Go Soeda. Several players advanced through qualifying, such as Alex Bolt, Marius Copil, Ernesto Escobedo, and Ramkumar Ramanathan, while Zhang Zhizhen entered as a lucky loser after a withdrawal.

The women’s draw also featured wildcards, awarded to Jodie Burrage, Samantha Murray Sharan, Matilda Mutavdzic, and Emma Raducanu. Qualifiers included Cristina Bucșa, Mayo Hibi, Monica Niculescu, Arina Rodionova, Storm Sanders, and Daria Snigur.

In the finals, Alex Bolt won the men’s singles title, and Alison Van Uytvanck claimed the women’s singles championship. The doubles trophies went to Marc Polmans and Matt Reid in the men’s event, and to Monica Niculescu and Elena-Gabriela Ruse in the women’s competition.

Shaba Hills Wildlife Reserve is a protected conservation area in northern Kenya, within Isiolo County. It was first set aside in the mid‑20th century as part of a broader network of game areas intended to safeguard wildlife and water sources in the arid north. Over time, its limits and management arrangements were refined, and today the reserve is overseen by local authorities in cooperation with national conservation bodies and nearby communities. Because it lies on a well-known safari circuit, several lodges and tented camps operate in and around the reserve, offering guided drives and nature walks.

Geographically, Shaba Hills lies close to other protected lands along the Ewaso Ng’iro River system, which acts as a natural corridor for wildlife moving between seasonal grazing and permanent water. The terrain is shaped by ancient volcanic activity: dark basalt outcrops, weathered lava terraces, and open plains that gently rise into low rocky ridges. These landforms influence drainage, creating pockets where groundwater reaches the surface as springs or seepage areas. The climate is characteristically hot and semi‑arid, with irregular rainfall and long dry periods that make access to reliable water especially important for both animals and people.

Vegetation varies with soil and moisture. Along riverbanks and seasonal channels, denser woodland can form, with tall acacias and palms providing shade and nesting sites. Away from water, drought-tolerant bushland dominates, including thorny shrubs and resinous species such as Commiphora. On exposed lava, plant cover becomes sparse, while occasional alkaline flats support tough grasses that green up quickly after rains. Succulents and flowering shrubs appear in scattered patches, adding brief bursts of color during favorable seasons. Some trees are valued locally for practical uses, such as chewing sticks for dental care and browse for livestock.

The reserve supports a wide range of wildlife adapted to dry landscapes. Zebras, giraffes, elephants, and antelope species such as gerenuk and oryx are common sights, while predators including lion, leopard, and cheetah follow the distribution of prey. Birds are especially diverse, from raptors riding thermals above the plains to waterbirds concentrated at pools. In the riverine sections, crocodiles and hippos may be present where deeper water persists.

Hospitals in Maine can be grouped by the communities they serve, reflecting the state’s mix of small coastal towns, inland regional hubs, and sparsely populated northern counties. In the capital area of Augusta (Kennebec County), major facilities include MaineGeneral Medical Center’s Alfond Center for Health, along with Riverview Psychiatric Center, a state psychiatric hospital that has operated under earlier names in the past.

Bangor (Penobscot County) functions as a key medical center for eastern Maine. Large institutions there include Northern Light Eastern Maine Medical Center, St. Joseph Hospital, Northern Light Acadia Hospital, and the Dorothea Dix Psychiatric Center, which also has a history of previous institutional names. Farther down the coast in Hancock County, Mount Desert Island Hospital serves Bar Harbor, while Northern Light Blue Hill Hospital supports the Blue Hill area. Ellsworth is home to Northern Light Maine Coast Hospital.

Several midcoast and central Maine towns host community hospitals. Belfast (Waldo County) has Waldo County General Hospital, and Rockport (Knox County) is served by Penobscot Bay Medical Center. In Brunswick (Cumberland County), Mid Coast Hospital is a key provider, and Portland, the largest city in Maine, includes Maine Medical Center and Northern Light Mercy Hospital. Westbrook also hosts Spring Harbor Hospital.

Rural regions rely on smaller hospitals that provide emergency care and basic inpatient services. Examples include Bridgton Hospital (Cumberland County), Calais Regional Hospital and Down East Community Hospital in Machias (Washington County), and Franklin Memorial Hospital in Farmington (Franklin County). Northern and western Maine facilities include Cary Medical Center in Caribou, Northern Maine Medical Center in Fort Kent, Houlton Regional Hospital, Northern Light A.R. Gould Hospital in Presque Isle, and Stephens Memorial Hospital in Norway. Additional community hospitals serve towns such as Lewiston, Skowhegan, Rumford, and Dover-Foxcroft, helping maintain access across long travel distances.

Liam Henderson (born 14 July 1979) is an Australian former lightweight rower who competed internationally in both sculling and sweep disciplines. Across a career spanning his junior years through to senior selection, he raced at major regattas including World Cups and World Championships, earned an under‑23 world title, and contributed to a medal-winning crew at the senior level.

**Club and state rowing**  
Henderson grew up in the Hawkesbury region of New South Wales and learned the sport through local river rowing before progressing to senior competition with the Hawkesbury River Rowing Club. Like many Australian lightweight athletes, he balanced domestic racing with selection trials that determined state and national crews.

His first significant domestic results came in age-category events, where he developed a reputation as a technically tidy sculler. Competing in club colours at the Australian Rowing Championships, he won a national under‑23 lightweight sculling title in the late 1990s. Those performances brought him to the attention of state selectors, and he later raced for New South Wales at the Interstate Regatta in the men’s lightweight four, the crew that contests the Penrith Cup. He appeared in that event more than once, reflecting consistent standing within the state’s lightweight squad.

**International representative rowing**  
Henderson’s Australian representative pathway began in the mid‑1990s, when he was selected for junior national crews. He first raced overseas as part of a quad scull at the Nations Cup (the major under‑23 regatta of the era), gaining early experience against European programs. In the same season he went on to contest the Junior World Rowing Championships, an event that often exposes young athletes to the demands of travel, unfamiliar conditions, and multi-round racing.

He also took part in a junior Trans‑Tasman series against New Zealand, a set of annual match races used by both countries to develop depth and evaluate emerging athletes. Returning the following year for the same series, he strengthened his case for under‑23 selection.

By 1997 Henderson had progressed into the under‑23 lightweight double scull, where he and his crewmate reached the podium at the World Rowing U23 Championships. The next step came in 1999, when he debuted in senior international competition at a World Rowing Cup regatta in the lightweight single scull. That season he peaked at the U23 World Championships, where he won the lightweight single scull and secured an under‑23 world championship title.

After transitioning from sculling into sweep rowing, Henderson earned selection in Australia’s men’s lightweight eight, a boat class that requires precise rhythm and high aerobic capacity. The crew achieved strong results on the World Cup circuit and later raced at the World Rowing Championships, where they finished on the medal dais. He continued to compete across both sculling and sweep boats into the early 2000s, including further World Cup appearances and a final World Championships campaign before retiring from international representation.

Friedrich Wilhelm Heller (3 May 1801 in Ulm – 18 February 1874 in Karlsruhe) was a German physician known for his work in internal medicine and anatomical research. He began his medical training at the universities of Würzburg and Munich, completing his doctorate in 1822. After finishing his studies, he broadened his practical experience by working in teaching hospitals in Prague and Leipzig, where he observed new approaches to bedside instruction and post‑mortem examination.

In 1825 Heller entered public service as a medical officer attached to a cavalry unit stationed near Mannheim. A few years later he moved to Karlsruhe, where he combined military duties with responsibilities at a civic hospital. In 1831 he undertook a study journey to Paris and Edinburgh, focusing on clinical methods, hospital organization, and the growing use of microscopy in pathology.

From 1834 until his retirement in 1866, Heller held a chair in clinical medicine at the University of Heidelberg. He delivered lectures on diagnosis and therapeutics and encouraged students to connect symptoms with organ changes seen in autopsy findings. Alongside his academic work, he served as a medical adviser to the government of Baden, contributing to discussions on sanitation, epidemic control, and the regulation of medical practice.

Heller is also remembered for early arguments that many diseases arise from alterations at the smallest structural level of tissues, a view that anticipated later cellular explanations in medicine. His publications included a study on inflammatory processes (1828), a collection of clinical case reports (1836), a two‑volume handbook of internal diseases (1845–1846), and a later essay on practical treatment principles (1865).

Ometepe Airport is the main air facility serving Ometepe, a large island located in Lake Nicaragua. It sits near the community of La Paloma in the municipality of Moyogalpa, within the Rivas Department, a short distance south of the town center. Opened in 2014 after a multi‑million‑dollar construction project, the airport was designed to fit the island’s narrow lowlands between the lake and the nearby volcanic terrain.

The runway lies close to the water’s edge, so aircraft approaching from the west typically fly over Lake Nicaragua. To the east, the land rises quickly toward the slopes of Concepción volcano, a prominent landmark that influences local flight paths and navigation considerations.

Pilots in the region also rely on radio navigation aids located on the mainland, including the Managua VOR/DME to the northwest and the Liberia VOR/DME farther to the south. These beacons help aircraft maintain routes and position, especially in changing weather.

Scheduled service is limited. One domestic carrier operates periodic circuit flights that connect the island with other Nicaraguan airports, including Managua on selected days. While the airport has facilities for immigration and customs, routine international commercial flights are not currently offered. Charter operations and private aircraft, such as small planes and helicopters, also use the terminal.

Imran Masood, HI(M), is a retired senior officer of the Pakistan Army who held several high-profile appointments at General Headquarters (GHQ), including service as Chief of General Staff during the early 2010s. The CGS role is widely regarded as one of the most influential staff positions in the army because it coordinates operational planning, manages inter-branch staff work, and supports the Chief of Army Staff in translating policy decisions into military directives. Over a long career, Masood built a reputation as an officer with experience spanning command, training, and strategic planning.

Masood was commissioned into the Armoured Corps in the mid-1970s after graduating from the Pakistan Military Academy. Like many officers who rise to the highest ranks, he completed a sequence of professional military education courses. These typically include the Command and Staff College in Quetta, where officers are trained in staff procedures and operational art, and the National Defence University in Islamabad, which focuses on higher-level strategy, civil-military relations, and national security policy. He also attended a foreign staff course in Turkey, reflecting the practice of sending selected officers abroad to broaden exposure to different doctrines and coalition planning methods.

During his mid-career years, Masood alternated between field command and staff responsibilities. He served as a brigade major in an armoured formation and later worked as an instructor at leading training institutions, including the Pakistan Military Academy and the School of Infantry and Tactics. Instructional postings are significant in the army’s career structure because they place officers in roles where they shape curricula, mentor younger officers, and contribute to professional standards. On the command side, he led an armoured regiment and later commanded brigades in both armoured and infantry settings, assignments that required balancing mobility, firepower, and coordination with supporting arms.

His staff experience included postings in the Military Operations Directorate, where officers handle operational monitoring, contingency planning, and coordination with corps headquarters. After promotion to major general in the mid-2000s, Masood commanded a mechanized division in southern Punjab, a role combining administration, training oversight, and readiness planning. He subsequently served as Director General of Inter-Services Public Relations, acting as the army’s principal spokesperson and overseeing public communication during a period of heightened security attention.

Later, he moved to GHQ’s planning and evaluation functions. As Director General Planning at the COAS Secretariat, he worked within a policy-focused environment often described as the army’s internal planning hub. He then served as Vice Chief of General Staff before promotion to lieutenant general and appointment as Inspector General Training and Evaluation, supervising training standards, exercises, and evaluation systems across formations. He ultimately became Chief of General Staff, after which he retired from active service.

Masood is married and has three children.

Sriboonruang Wittayakarn School, often known locally as Sibunrueang, is a major public secondary school in Nong Bua Lamphu Province, northeastern Thailand. The campus is situated in Ban Santisuk (Mu 13) within Sriboonrueng District and serves as one of the central educational institutions for students in the surrounding communities. Administratively, the school operates under the regional Secondary Educational Service Area Office responsible for overseeing public secondary education in the province.

The school’s establishment is closely tied to the limited access to upper-level schooling in earlier decades. Before the mid-1970s, many students who completed primary education in the district faced difficulties continuing their studies because the nearest secondary schools were located far away and transportation options were limited. Local leaders and residents therefore pushed for a district-based secondary school. Initial planning began several years earlier, but the effort progressed slowly until district authorities compiled the necessary documentation and submitted it to national education agencies. Formal approval was granted in 1974, marking the beginning of the school as an official government institution.

When the school first opened to students in 1974, it started with only a small number of classes and a modest first intake. Demand quickly increased, and over time the school expanded its buildings, teaching staff, and grade-level offerings. Today it provides both lower secondary and upper secondary education, with a range of academic programs designed to prepare students for higher education and vocational pathways. Like many Thai secondary schools, it also tracks performance through national assessments in core subjects such as Thai language, mathematics, science, social studies, and English.

Ralph McQuarrie (1929–2012) was an American illustrator and conceptual artist whose futuristic imagery helped shape the look of modern science-fiction film. He is most widely associated with the original Star Wars trilogy, where his paintings guided sets, costumes, vehicles, and the overall atmosphere of a galaxy far from Earth. McQuarrie’s work is often described as a bridge between written ideas and what audiences eventually see on screen, translating scripts into believable worlds through detailed visual planning.

McQuarrie was born in Gary, Indiana, and developed an interest in drawing and engineering-related subjects early in life. After serving in the U.S. Army, he studied at the Art Center School in Los Angeles, building a foundation in illustration and design. Before entering the film industry, he worked as a commercial artist, producing technical and promotional artwork that required clarity, precision, and strong draftsmanship—skills that later proved useful in concept design.

His transition into entertainment design accelerated in the mid-1970s, when filmmaker George Lucas sought visual development for a space adventure that had not yet been fully realized on film. McQuarrie produced a series of paintings that established key ideas for Star Wars, including interpretations of characters, spacecraft, and environments. Several of his designs directly influenced elements that became iconic, and his artwork was frequently used as a reference point for construction teams and special-effects departments. In this way, his paintings were not merely marketing images; they functioned as practical blueprints for production.

Following this breakthrough, McQuarrie contributed to other major projects, continuing to refine the visual language of science fiction. He worked on Close Encounters of the Third Kind, developing concepts related to spacecraft and lighting. Later, he provided designs for The Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi, helping to expand the universe introduced in the first film. He also contributed to E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, where his work supported the creation of locations, props, and mood.

A notable aspect of McQuarrie’s approach was his ability to make imaginative technology appear functional. He often combined real-world industrial details with dramatic composition, suggesting how a machine might be built, used, and maintained. This grounded quality helped audiences accept extraordinary settings as coherent places. Although concept art is typically produced behind the scenes, McQuarrie’s images became widely circulated through books, exhibitions, and documentaries, highlighting the importance of visual development in filmmaking.

McQuarrie’s legacy rests on the idea that design can define a story’s identity. By providing a consistent visual direction early in production, he influenced not only individual films but also the broader expectations of what cinematic science fiction could look like.

Marco Bianchi (born 12 March 1950) is an Italian economist and academic based in Rome. He has spent much of his career at Sapienza University of Rome, where he completed his university studies and earned a degree in Economics in the early 1970s. His training was grounded in both economic theory and institutional analysis, an approach that later informed his teaching and administrative work within the university.

Over the years, Bianchi has held several governance and leadership positions connected to Sapienza’s Faculty of Law. In addition to teaching economics-related subjects to law students, he has coordinated initiatives aimed at strengthening the links between legal studies, public finance, and the organization of markets. He has served as head of an institute focused on economic and financial matters within the faculty, and has also taken responsibilities connected to internal evaluation procedures, such as reviewing teaching quality and supporting the assessment of departmental performance.

Beyond his roles at the university, Bianchi has contributed to national research oversight. He has acted as a reviewer for competitive research programs funded by the Italian Ministry responsible for universities and scientific research, evaluating proposals and monitoring ongoing projects. He has also participated in internal inspection and compliance activities, which in Italian universities often involve checking administrative regularity and ensuring that academic structures follow established regulations.

His involvement in postgraduate education includes participation in scientific committees for doctoral and master’s programs, particularly in areas where economics intersects with commercial law, European private law, and public policy. In these settings, he has helped define curricula, assess academic standards, and supervise research paths for early-career scholars.

During the earlier phase of his career, Bianchi received recognition for his graduation thesis, which was awarded in a competition sponsored by a local banking foundation. He has also served on academic selection panels at the national level, taking part in evaluation commissions for appointments and promotions across different ranks of the Italian university system.

Bianchi’s professional profile reflects a combination of scholarship, institutional service, and participation in research evaluation, typical of senior Italian academics working at large public universities.

Kandola Kalan is a rural settlement in the Shaheed Bhagat Singh Nagar district of Punjab, India. It lies within the Doaba region and is connected to nearby market towns by local roads. For postal and administrative purposes, the village falls under the service area of a nearby head post office, while the district headquarters at Nawanshahr and the state capital Chandigarh can be reached by road. Like most villages in Punjab, local civic matters are handled through a Gram Panchayat system, led by a Sarpanch who is chosen through village-level elections.

According to the 2011 Census of India, Kandola Kalan had 372 households and a population of 1,734 residents. Of these, 904 were males and 830 were females. The village reported a literacy rate of 79.6%, which is above the overall literacy level recorded for Punjab in the same census period. Children aged six and below numbered 171, representing just under one-tenth of the total population. The child sex ratio was notably higher than the state average, indicating a comparatively larger number of girls per thousand boys in the youngest age group.

Social composition in the village includes a substantial share of residents belonging to Scheduled Castes, forming roughly two-thirds of the population. As in many parts of this district, the Scheduled Tribe population is either very small or not recorded. Work participation figures show that 658 people were engaged in some form of economic activity, including 497 men and 161 women. Most workers were classified as main workers, meaning they were employed for more than six months of the year, while the remaining group carried out seasonal or short-term work.

In education, the village is served by a Punjabi-medium government school offering primary and upper primary classes. The school follows national guidelines for free and compulsory schooling for children aged 6 to 14 and provides cooked meals under the Mid-Day Meal programme. For higher education, students typically commute to colleges in nearby towns such as Banga or Nawanshahr, while larger private universities are accessible in other parts of Punjab.

For transport, the nearest railway facilities are found in the surrounding towns, with broader connectivity available from larger stations in the district. Domestic air travel is generally accessed through the airport in Ludhiana, while international flights are available from Chandigarh and Amritsar.

Emma Chambers (1848–1933) was an English mezzo-soprano and stage performer whose career bridged Victorian London and the rapidly growing theatrical scene of Australia. Known for lively character work as well as singing roles, she became especially familiar to audiences in the Australian colonies during the 1880s and early 1890s.

Chambers first gained wide notice in London through parts that mixed music with comedy and disguise. Early successes included breeches roles in which she played male characters onstage, a popular convention in the period. Her appearances at prominent venues helped establish her reputation for energetic acting and clear vocal delivery, and she soon moved between pantomime, comic plays, and light opera—genres that drew large mixed audiences and relied on performers with versatility rather than purely operatic technique.

During the mid-1870s she worked under contract in productions of fashionable continental operettas, which were often adapted for English stages. These engagements placed her in a circuit of major London theatres where French and German works were translated, revised, and mounted with elaborate staging. She later took on named roles in well-known operettas by composers such as Lecocq and Planquette, including a notable engagement at a central London theatre arranged by a leading theatre proprietor of the day. By 1880 she was also appearing in English comic opera, reflecting the period’s appetite for locally written works that blended popular song styles with theatrical comedy.

In October 1884 Chambers travelled to Australia under contract to a major theatrical partnership to repeat a role that had brought her recognition in Britain. Melbourne audiences, in particular, welcomed imported performers from London, and Chambers quickly became part of touring companies that carried large-scale productions between colonial capitals. Over the next years she appeared in a range of popular dramas and melodramas, taking on parts that demanded strong characterisation as much as vocal ability.

In 1889 she left Australia for South Africa with a company formed under her leadership, travelling by steamship with members of her family and troupe. After a visit to England in 1891, she returned again to the southern hemisphere, passing through South Africa and then Australia, where she performed in a production mounted by a leading actor-manager.

By the early twentieth century Chambers was back on the English stage, including a substantial role in a London theatre in 1901. In her personal life she married Albert Marsh, who also acted as her manager, and she was at times associated with another married name. She died in 1933, remembered as a capable, adaptable performer whose career followed the pathways of the British Empire’s theatre circuits.

The 4th Canadian Film Awards took place on April 27, 1952, recognizing notable work in Canadian cinema across a range of formats. The event was presided over by Sidney Earle Smith, who at the time served as president of the University of Toronto. Awards were organized into categories that reflected both theatrical productions and films made for educational or institutional use, with additional acknowledgements given through honourable mentions.

In the top prize category, Film of the Year went to *Newfoundland Scene*, produced by F. R. Crawley. The award for Theatrical Feature was presented to *Royal Journey*, credited to David Bairstow, Gudrun Parker, and Roger Blais, while *Little Aurore’s Tragedy (La petite Aurore, l’enfant martyre)* received an honourable mention. The Theatrical Short category recognized *Opera School* (Gudrun Parker), alongside honourable mentions for *The Fruitful Earth*, *Man in the Peace Tower*, and *Struggle for Oil*.

Non-theatrical awards were further divided by sponsorship. *Newfoundland Scene* also won in the open non-theatrical division, with other works cited for distinction, including *The Longhouse People* and *Les Moines de Saint-Benoît-du-Lac*. In government-sponsored non-theatrical film, *Milk Made* received the main award, and *Ski à Québec* was commended. *Packaged Power* led the non-government sponsored group, while several club and university productions were also acknowledged. A special award honoured Norman McLaren for innovative research reflected in *Around Is Around* and *Now Is the Time*.

BWI Group (BeijingWest Industries) is an automotive components supplier specializing in braking and suspension technologies. The company is headquartered in Beijing, China, and serves a broad customer base that includes passenger car makers, motorcycle brands, and manufacturers of specialized vehicles. A major turning point came in 2009, when BWI acquired Delphi’s Chassis Division, adding established product lines and engineering capability to its portfolio. The acquisition was reported at roughly $100 million and helped position the firm as a global supplier.

Although the BWI name dates from the 2009 transaction, much of the technical heritage behind its products traces back to earlier North American chassis and brake organizations that evolved through multiple corporate names over the 20th century. This long development path reflects the way braking and suspension systems have advanced from primarily mechanical devices to integrated, electronically controlled safety platforms.

BWI’s manufacturing footprint is international, with production operations in several regions, including China and a number of European locations such as Poland, the United Kingdom, and the Czech Republic, along with facilities in Mexico. This spread supports proximity to vehicle assembly plants and helps meet regional supply requirements.

The product range has expanded over time from early shock absorbers to sophisticated chassis systems. Historical milestones include drum brake hydraulics, welded damper designs, vacuum brake boosters, and the introduction of disc brake components. Later decades brought anti-lock braking systems, modular struts, electronic stability control, and adaptive damping technologies. In the 2000s, magnetorheological damping systems became prominent, and ABS solutions were extended to motorcycle applications.

Ashani Kemarley Brown (born 20 July 1992) is a sprinter known for racing the 100 metres and 200 metres. Competing at elite level, he has recorded a best of 9.93 seconds over 100 m, a time that places him among the faster athletes of his generation. His career has included representing more than one nation and combining athletics with studies in the United States.

Brown began his international exposure while still a junior athlete for Jamaica. One of his earliest achievements came in relay competition, where he helped Jamaica’s 4 × 100 metres team secure a medal at the CARIFTA Games in 2011. That success suggested strong promise, although his progress was later slowed by injuries that disrupted training and competition during a key development period.

To continue both education and sport, Brown relocated to the United States and enrolled at Merritt College in Oakland, California. Competing in the American junior college system, he made steady improvements, particularly in strength and race durability. He became a leading performer at the California Community College level and earned state titles in the 100 m. A major breakthrough came at the CCCAA State Track and Field Championships in 2014, where he ran 9.93 seconds. The performance was significant not only as a personal best, but also for its standing within junior college athletics, and it ranked highly worldwide for that season. In the same year, he also posted a 200 m best of 20.38 seconds, placing him competitively on international seasonal lists.

In 2015, Brown continued racing on the Caribbean circuit, including appearances at meets in Kingston. Later that year he initiated a change in sporting nationality, requesting a transfer of allegiance from Jamaica to Bahrain. Such moves are governed by international athletics regulations and typically involve approval processes before an athlete can represent a new country in major championships.

Brown went on to compete for Bahrain at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. In the men’s 100 m, he progressed through the opening round and reached the semi-finals, running 10.13 seconds in the qualifying stage. His primary personal bests remain 9.93 seconds for 100 m and 20.38 seconds for 200 m, both achieved in 2014.

What Remains is a short work by the German author Christa Wolf that explores the psychological effects of political monitoring in the former German Democratic Republic. Although it was composed in 1979, it appeared in print only in 1990, a delay that reflects the political sensitivities surrounding its subject and the changes that followed the collapse of East Germany.

The narrative follows a single ordinary day experienced by an unnamed woman who senses that state security agents are tracking her movements and professional life. Instead of focusing on dramatic events, the text concentrates on how constant observation reshapes routine behavior. Simple actions—answering the phone, speaking with friends, leaving the apartment—become calculated choices. The protagonist’s home no longer feels private; it becomes a space where every word might be recorded or misinterpreted.

Wolf presents surveillance not only as an external system but also as an internal condition. The woman begins to scrutinize herself as harshly as she imagines others do. Doubt and anxiety influence her body as well as her thoughts, producing signs of stress such as sleeplessness and nervous agitation. Social life shrinks because trust becomes difficult: casual conversations are replaced by guarded remarks, hints, and indirect language.

A recurring element is her fascination with the watchers themselves. She wonders about their motives, their everyday habits, and whether they can separate their work from their private lives. This curiosity reveals how surveillance creates a distorted relationship between observer and observed, binding them together even without direct contact.

Told in a reflective first-person voice, the novella draws readers into an ongoing inner commentary. By the end, encounters with younger people at a public reading suggest that fear can be challenged, and that speaking openly may eventually become possible—even if the legacy of suspicion remains.

A large carved elephant tusk showing episodes from the Buddha’s life is displayed in the Decorative Arts gallery of the National Museum in New Delhi. The object is fashioned from a single, intact tusk and measures close to five feet in length. It entered the museum collection as a donation and is generally attributed to skilled ivory workers active in the Delhi area in the early decades of the twentieth century. The tusk is notable both for its scale and for the dense narrative program cut into its curved surface.

Carving on whole tusks became an admired form of luxury craft in India during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, with Delhi recognized as an important center, along with workshops in Burma. Comparable full-tusk carvings are known in parts of West and Central Africa as well, though those were typically made from African elephant ivory. In South Asia, ivory working has a long history: classical literature mentions finely made ivory objects, and archaeological finds indicate the presence of carved pieces from at least the early centuries of the Common Era. The practice expanded in regions such as Assam and Mysore, where access to elephants and support from royal courts helped sustain specialist artisans. Because ivory was widely traded, raw material and finished works circulated to places where patrons valued the craft.

The New Delhi tusk presents a continuous visual biography of the Buddha through forty-three circular medallions arranged in a spiraling sequence. The lower portion begins with events associated with his birth and youth and continues through key moments leading to awakening. The upper medallions then move to episodes after enlightenment, culminating in his final passing. While many scenes echo established Buddhist sculpture and painting, the tusk also includes less frequently illustrated moments, such as an early encounter involving compassion toward an injured animal and reflections that emphasize ethical change and the reality of death.

As the tusk narrows toward the tip, the carving shifts from narrative medallions to prominent iconic figures. Here, several well-known hand gestures are shown, including the earth-touching gesture, the gesture of reassurance, and the gesture associated with teaching. A band of scrolling floral ornament winds between the medallions, linking the episodes and providing a decorative framework for the story as it rises from base to tip.

The Washington Road Elm Allée is a notable segment of Washington Road in West Windsor, New Jersey, where rows of elm trees frame the roadway and shape a distinctive approach to Princeton University. The tree-lined corridor passes through open university-owned fields and, together with the nearby crossing over Lake Carnegie, creates a strong visual gateway into the campus area. At the northern end of this landscaped stretch, the Delaware and Raritan Canal runs close to the road, linking the allée to one of central New Jersey’s best-known historic waterways.

A paved running and walking route follows the allée and serves as a connector between several destinations. From this corridor, pedestrians can continue onto the canal towpath, head toward Princeton’s main campus, or branch off onto additional trails that weave through surrounding meadows and farmland. Because it combines scenic views with practical access, the route is used for recreation as well as daily travel by students, residents, and visitors.

The planting of the original allée dates to the early twentieth century, when Princeton Nurseries played a major role in regional landscape projects. The trees were chosen for their upright form and their ability to create a shaded arch overhead as they matured. The Princeton Elm, a cultivated variety associated with the nursery, became particularly valued for its appearance and for improved tolerance to Dutch elm disease, which devastated elm populations across the United States. Over the decades, the allée has inevitably changed: some of the original trees have been lost to age, storms, and disease, while others have survived and grown into large specimens. To preserve the characteristic look of the corridor, replacement plantings have been added at different times, including other elm cultivars as well as a smaller number of non-elm trees.

Just east of the roadway, near the path, lies a small historic cemetery known as the Schenck-Covenhoven Burial Ground, also referred to locally as the Old Conover Graveyard. Enclosed by a stone boundary, it contains several dozen graves and is considered one of the oldest burial sites in the township, with interments dating back to the mid-1700s. The families associated with the site were early Dutch farming settlers in the area, and although the cemetery has not been used for many generations, it is still cared for on a limited basis.

The CECAFA Club Cup is a regional football competition for club teams affiliated with the Council for East and Central Africa Football Associations (CECAFA). The event brings together leading sides from the association’s member countries and serves as an important platform for clubs that may not regularly appear in continental tournaments. Since the early 2000s, the tournament has also been widely referred to under a sponsored name, reflecting the role of external backing in keeping the competition active.

The origins of the cup go back to the late 1960s, when an early edition was played but later treated as unofficial in many records. After that initial attempt, the tournament experienced interruptions and did not develop into a consistent annual event until later in the 1970s, when a champion was formally recognised. Over time, the competition has continued to face occasional cancellations, often due to scheduling difficulties, funding constraints, or wider organisational issues.

Match outcomes in the CECAFA Club Cup have frequently been decided in knockout rounds. When finals end level after regulation time and extra time, champions are determined through penalty shootouts, which are recorded alongside the scoreline. Lists of winners typically distinguish between champions and runners-up and may include notes on club name changes and how titles are counted. Statistics are also commonly summarised by nation to show which countries’ clubs have been most successful.

Samuel L.
