Rabinowitz (April 12, 1881 – June 3, 1938) was a Russian-born Jewish-American attorney, public official, and municipal judge associated with New York City politics in the early twentieth century. His career reflected a common path for immigrants of his generation: public schooling, professional training, work in local party organizations, and eventual service in government.

Rabinowitz was born on April 12, 1881 in Odessa, then part of the Russian Empire, to Leon and Fannie Rabinowitz. He arrived in the United States as a child and spent much of his youth on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, an area known for dense immigrant neighborhoods and active political clubs. He attended New York City public schools and later enrolled at the College of the City of New York, studying there from 1897 to 1900. Seeking a legal career, he continued to New York Law School and completed his degree in 1902. After admission to the bar, he opened a practice in lower Manhattan, maintaining offices near City Hall where many lawyers handled court and municipal matters.

Soon after establishing his practice, Rabinowitz became involved in Democratic Party organizations in his assembly district. He joined local political clubs, attended ward meetings, and worked on campaigns, activities that provided experience and connections in an era when party structures strongly influenced nominations and appointments. His visibility within the district helped him win election to the New York State Assembly, where he represented a Manhattan constituency beginning in 1909. He served two terms, focusing on legislation related to city administration, public safety, and court procedure. Though identified with the Democratic organization, he also gained support from reform-minded voters during a period when New York politics included frequent challenges from independent movements.

After leaving the Assembly, Rabinowitz returned to private practice while remaining active in civic affairs. He participated in legal associations and served on committees that addressed municipal governance and court efficiency. In 1926, he was elected to the Municipal Court of the City of New York, a busy trial court that handled a large volume of civil cases and minor criminal matters. As a judge, he was known for a steady courtroom style and attention to the practical effects of rulings on working residents and small businesses.

Rabinowitz married Rebecca Stein, and they had two children, Philip and Marian. He died on June 3, 1938 after a short illness and was buried at a Jewish cemetery in Queens. His professional life illustrates how immigrant lawyers could move from neighborhood advocacy to formal roles in New York’s legal and political institutions.

Hans Richter (6 April 1888 – 1 February 1976) was a German painter, filmmaker, and writer known for connecting the European avant‑garde with the emerging language of experimental cinema. Active as both an organizer and a creator, he helped introduce abstract film to wider audiences and worked across several countries as political conditions in Europe shifted. His career illustrates how modernist art, journalism, and film production often overlapped in the first half of the twentieth century.

Richter was born in Berlin into a middle‑class family and trained in art at academies in Germany. During the First World War he became involved in artistic circles that questioned traditional forms and institutions. After the war he joined the Dada movement, collaborating with poets, designers, and musicians who favored collage, chance methods, and sharp cultural critique. These contacts were important because they provided a network of publishers, editors, and patrons who could support new work outside established galleries and studios.

In the early 1920s Richter began making abstract films that explored rhythm, contrast, and movement rather than narrative. Works such as *Rhythmus 21* and *Rhythmus 23* used animated geometric forms to investigate how editing and visual repetition could create a sense of time comparable to music. At a moment when cinema was still associated mainly with theatrical storytelling, these films argued that motion pictures could also function as a modern visual art. Richter wrote essays and gave lectures to explain these ideas, treating film as a distinct medium with its own grammar.

Alongside his filmmaking, he undertook editorial and organizational roles. He contributed to art journals, worked with exhibition groups, and promoted international exchanges between artists. This public work was not separate from his artistic output: it helped build an audience and a critical vocabulary for experimental film and modern design. During the late Weimar period he also collaborated with other filmmakers and photographers who were developing documentary and city‑film approaches, showing his ability to move between abstraction and socially oriented projects.

The political upheavals of the 1930s reshaped Richter’s life. As the Nazi regime targeted modernist artists and those with left‑leaning associations, he left Germany and lived in several European countries before eventually moving to the United States. In New York he taught, wrote about film history and technique, and continued to make and support independent productions. His work as a teacher mattered because it connected early European experimentation with later American avant‑garde cinema.

Richter’s legacy lies in his insistence that film could be both an artistic experiment and a form of critical commentary. By combining creative practice with editorial advocacy, he helped establish experimental cinema as a recognized field within twentieth‑century culture.

Heathfield Park is a historic country estate in the village of Old Heathfield, East Sussex. The property is notable for its long sequence of owners, repeated architectural changes, and landscaped grounds that include both designed features and areas valued for wildlife.

The estate began life in the late seventeenth century as a private mansion set within parkland. Work started in 1677 under James Plummer, and further building followed in the early eighteenth century under Raymond Blackmore. Like many English country houses, it evolved in response to the tastes and ambitions of successive proprietors rather than being built to a single fixed plan.

A major turning point came in the 1760s when George Augustus Eliott acquired the property after accumulating significant wealth through military service, including prize money connected with the 1762 siege of Havana. Soon after his purchase, the house was expanded and updated in 1766 to designs by Robert Taylor, an architect who later received a knighthood. Eliott retained the estate until his death in 1790, and the house subsequently took the name Heathfield Park in recognition of his title.

In the following year, the new owner Francis Newbery, whose family was connected to the publisher John Newbery, employed landscape designer Humphrey Repton to improve the grounds. One of the most distinctive elements of the estate dates from this period: the Gibraltar Tower, built as a commemorative structure celebrating Eliott’s role in the defence of Gibraltar during the siege of 1779–1782. The tower combines an octagonal lower stage with a circular upper section, and visitors reach the top via a spiral stair contained within. It is listed at Grade II*, reflecting its architectural and historic interest.

During the nineteenth century, the estate served for decades as the home of the Blunt baronet family. Later, the art patron William Cleverley Alexander undertook a substantial remodelling in 1895, commissioning Sir Reginald Blomfield to reshape the house in a Georgian Revival manner. Among the visible changes were the replacement of stucco with brick facing and the addition of a new wing. Alexander died in 1916 after a fall inside the house.

In the mid-twentieth century the estate entered a new phase when Gerald Moore purchased it in 1963. He opened the gardens to the public, introduced equestrian facilities, restored the Gibraltar Tower in 1970, and later developed a wildlife park. The property was sold in 1993 and remains privately owned today.

Beyond its buildings, Heathfield Park includes an area designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest. This status recognises the ecological value of the local ghyll woodland habitat and its county-important lichen communities. Part of the grounds also hosts Heathfield Park Cricket Club, established in 1878 and still supporting matches and training for adults and juniors.

The Department of Civil, Geo and Environmental Engineering at the Technical University of Munich is based on the university’s Munich campus and brings together disciplines that deal with the built environment and natural systems. Its work spans classic civil engineering, the study of the Earth, and environmental technologies, with research and teaching aimed at improving infrastructure, managing resources, and understanding geological processes.

Within the department, chairs and research groups are commonly organized into several thematic clusters. One major area covers construction and building design, including energy-conscious architecture, building physics, and structural systems made from concrete, masonry, steel, and timber. Related fields examine construction materials and their performance, ranging from materials testing to methods that evaluate structures without causing damage.

A second cluster focuses on mobility and transportation. This includes traffic operations and control, as well as the planning and engineering of roads, railways, and airfields. Researchers also analyze transport systems and urban mobility patterns using modeling and simulation, supporting decisions in city and regional planning.

A third area concentrates on mechanics and management within engineering practice. Topics such as computational and structural mechanics, risk and reliability, and construction management address how complex projects are designed, assessed, and delivered. Real estate and infrastructure management may also be represented, reflecting the economic and organizational side of the built environment.

The fourth cluster highlights hydro- and geosciences. Research may involve hydrology, groundwater, river basin management, geothermal systems, landslides, and engineering geology, alongside urban water engineering and hydraulic design.

In addition, associated members contribute expertise in fields like geodesy, remote sensing, geoinformatics, land management, landscape planning, environmental monitoring, and digital fabrication. International subject rankings periodically evaluate the department’s broader fields, with positions varying by ranking organization and year.

Lillias Margaret Skene (née Hamilton; 28 March 1867–25 March 1957) is remembered as an Australian advocate for women and a long-serving community organiser whose work linked social reform with practical support services.

Born in Smythesdale, Victoria, on 28 March 1867, she was the third child of John Prendergast Hamilton, a police magistrate originally from Scotland, and Agnes Margaret Hamilton (née Buchanan), who had English family connections. She was educated locally and later attended Alexandra College, where her schooling reflected the expectations of middle-class families at the time: a strong emphasis on discipline, civic responsibility, and preparation for public life through voluntary service.

On 7 November 1888, at St Mary’s Anglican Church in Caulfield, she married David Alexander Skene, a sheepmaster. Their early married years were marked by financial uncertainty, which shaped the family’s repeated moves and influenced Skene’s later interest in welfare and health initiatives. When employment drew her husband to New South Wales, she remained in Victoria with their children for extended periods, managing household responsibilities and maintaining family stability. The family reunited at rural stations near Bourke and later relocated several times in response to changing prospects in pastoral work.

In 1900 they moved to Manly, Sydney, where they attempted to earn a living from a small dairy operation on leased land. Drought conditions and the cost of fodder made the venture difficult, and by 1906 they returned to Melbourne. There, David Skene shifted into commercial work as a woolbroker and stock and station agent. In 1910, funds inherited from Lillias Skene’s mother enabled the purchase of a family home in South Yarra, providing a firmer base for her public activities.

Skene became involved in organised women’s networks in Victoria, including the National Council of Women. Working as an assistant secretary, she supported coordination between affiliated groups and helped sustain campaigns concerned with women’s status and social improvement. She also contributed to health administration, serving in roles connected to the governance of a women’s hospital committee and, during the First World War era, managing stores and operations for a Melbourne home hospital connected with Government House.

After gradually stepping back from many responsibilities in 1949, she moved to Brighton. She died in Armadale on 25 March 1957 and was buried at Brighton Cemetery. Her name endures in Skene Street in the Canberra suburb of Cook, reflecting recognition of her civic contribution.

Ada Developers Academy is an intensive training program designed to prepare women and gender-expansive adults for entry-level roles in software development, particularly those who have not previously worked as professional programmers. One distinguishing feature of the academy is its tuition-free model, which helps reduce financial barriers to career change. To support participants with day-to-day costs while studying, the program also allows students to seek a small, low-interest loan intended for living expenses.

The curriculum is structured to combine guided instruction with real-world experience. Students typically begin with several months of full-time classroom learning, where they build a foundation in core programming concepts and modern web development practices. Coursework commonly emphasizes languages and tools used in industry, such as Python for backend development, JavaScript for interactive web applications, and frameworks and libraries used to build full products. Alongside coding skills, students study computer science essentials—topics like problem-solving approaches, data structures, and collaborative workflows that are necessary in professional engineering teams. HTML and CSS are also covered to support front-end fundamentals and user-facing design implementation.

After the instructional portion, participants move into a multi-month paid internship. These placements are hosted by technology companies in the Seattle area and are intended to give students experience working on production code, receiving feedback through code review, and collaborating with cross-functional teams. Partner organizations have included well-known firms across e-commerce, enterprise software, and consumer technology.

Ada started in the Seattle tech community and has grown with support from corporate sponsorships, private donations, and other public or community funding sources. Sponsors may contribute financially, offer mentors, and provide internship opportunities, while also sharing input about industry needs. Many companies engage with programs like this to broaden their hiring pipelines and strengthen diversity within technical roles.

San Esteban is one of the municipalities located in the northeastern part of Honduras, within the department of Olancho. It lies between several well-known localities in the region: Dulce Nombre de Culmí is to the east, Gualaco to the west, and Catacamas to the south. The area has also appeared in literature, since a Costa Rican novelist, Óscar Núñez Oliva, used San Esteban as the setting for a novel published in 2000.

The municipality’s name commemorates friar Esteban Verdelete, a religious figure remembered for his work in spreading Christianity among communities in the zone. Local tradition identifies 1808 as the year of its establishment, linked to friar José Antonio Liendo y Goicoechea, who traveled from Guatemala and played a role in organizing the settlement. In its early years, the population included indigenous inhabitants who already lived in the surrounding lands.

Geographically, San Esteban occupies a section of the Agalta Valley and is traversed by the Grande de Agalta River, which is an important feature for the landscape and local agriculture. Its territory shares borders with Trujillo and Iriona to the north, Catacamas to the south, Dulce Nombre de Culmí to the east, and Gualaco to the west. Administratively, it includes more than twenty villages distributed across its valleys and hillsides.

*The Ghost-Seer* (German: *Der Geisterseher – Aus den Papieren des Grafen von O***) is a prose work by Friedrich Schiller that occupies an unusual place in his career. Rather than being released at once as a finished book, it first reached readers in parts between 1787 and 1789 in Schiller’s periodical *Thalia*. Only later was it gathered and issued in multiple volumes. This publication history is important because the text reflects its serial origins: it shifts in pacing and emphasis, and it does not form a perfectly unified narrative arc.

The story is presented as a first-person account attributed to an unnamed “Count of O**,” who frames what follows as testimony rather than invention. He underscores that the events he describes may sound implausible but insists on their factuality, and he adopts the stance of a narrator who claims to have nothing to gain from persuading his readers. This device creates an atmosphere of documentary authenticity, which becomes especially effective as the plot moves into the territory of deception, staged marvels, and secret influence.

At the center of the narrative is a German prince who travels to Venice during the carnival season. The Venetian setting is not merely decorative: masks, anonymity, and spectacle support a sequence of encounters in which appearances are difficult to verify. The prince is gradually drawn into a web of manipulation involving a clandestine religious-political network, often described in terms of Jesuit intrigue. Their objective is to reshape his convictions and steer his future rule, using theatrical tricks and purported supernatural phenomena to break down his resistance and redirect his loyalties.

Alongside its sensational elements, the work also gestures toward the intellectual climate of the late Enlightenment. Schiller uses the prince’s predicament to explore tensions between impulse and ethical restraint, personal desire and public obligation. Digressions on religion, history, and the uses of power reveal a skeptical attitude toward institutional authority and highlight the period’s fascination with rational critique, even when the plot is fueled by apparitions and conspiracies.

Although Schiller never completed the novel, it achieved wide popularity in his lifetime, partly because it borrowed motifs associated with Gothic fiction—spiritualism, secret societies, and ominous “proofs” of the beyond. Readers and commentators have sometimes linked its themes to contemporary fascination with occult showmen and staged séances. The book also traveled early: an English version appeared around 1800, helping to establish its reputation outside German-speaking audiences. Later attempts to supply an ending, including a continuation published in the twentieth century, did not fully replace the appeal of the fragment as Schiller left it: a hybrid of philosophical inquiry and suspenseful illusion.

Ronnie Shields is an American football player known for lining up at tight end, and he has spent time seeking opportunities at the professional level. Born in Los Angeles to Ron and Victoria Shields, he later moved to Georgia and attended Stephenson High School in Stone Mountain, finishing in 2010. Notably, he was a late starter in the sport, only taking up football during his junior year of high school, yet he developed enough to attract college interest.

Shields committed to the University of Kentucky in late 2009 and arrived on campus in the summer of 2010. He remained with the Wildcats program through 2014, building his experience at the collegiate level in a competitive conference.

After college, Shields entered the 2015 NFL Draft but was not selected. He worked to earn a roster spot by attending the Seattle Seahawks’ rookie minicamp that May, though it did not immediately result in a contract. Early in 2016, Seattle signed him to a futures deal, a type of agreement commonly used to bring players into offseason programs. Over the following months, he was waived, brought back, and later released again with an injury designation as roster decisions were made ahead of the season.

Vzyado was an Argentine post-punk group from Buenos Aires that emerged in 1982 during a period of rapid growth in the city’s independent music circuit. The band became known for a tense, rhythmic sound built on sharp guitar patterns, elastic bass lines, and vocal delivery that shifted between spoken and melodic phrases. Critics often linked their approach to the broader post-punk movement, citing parallels with British and Latin American acts that blended punk energy with funk-inflected grooves and experimental arrangements. Although their initial run was short, Vzyado later returned for a series of reunion performances and releases.

The band formed when bassist Paula Rinaldi and vocalist-guitarist Martín “Tino” Ledesma began collaborating after meeting at small concerts in the San Telmo area. They soon recruited guitarist Federico Sosa, whose interest in angular, percussive playing complemented Rinaldi’s driving bass work, and drummer Javier Paredes, who had previously played in local new wave projects. From the beginning, Vzyado rehearsed and recorded with limited resources, which pushed them toward a stripped-down style emphasizing rhythm and texture over polished production.

Their first full-length record, Grabación en Taller, appeared in 1984 through a small independent imprint that specialized in underground rock. Despite its title suggesting a concert album, it was actually recorded live in a rehearsal space with minimal overdubs. The choice was partly aesthetic, but also practical: studio time was expensive, and the group wanted to capture the intensity of their stage sound. The album circulated widely via tape trading and college radio, helping the band build a reputation beyond Buenos Aires.

In 1985, internal scheduling pressures began to affect the lineup. Sosa increasingly focused on a separate project that was gaining commercial attention, and he departed later that year. As a trio, Vzyado recorded their second album, Entre Sombras, released in 1986. Compared with the debut, it featured more space in the arrangements and a heavier use of repetitive motifs, reflecting the band’s interest in dance rhythms and early industrial textures. Shortly after the album’s release, the group stopped performing. Members later pointed to uneven promotion, financial difficulties, and growing personal responsibilities as key factors in the decision.

Vzyado resurfaced in 2004, with Rinaldi and Ledesma returning alongside a new drummer, Nicolás Albornoz, after Paredes had moved abroad. The reunion led to festival appearances and club dates, and several older tracks were licensed for an international compilation focused on Latin American post-punk. In 2009, the band released a short EP, Rastro, their first new material in over two decades. Activity gradually slowed in the following years, and the project ended after Ledesma’s death in 2016.

Over time, Vzyado came to represent a particular strand of South American post-punk: resourceful, rhythm-centered, and shaped as much by local scenes as by global influences.

UEFA Group H formed part of the European qualifying programme for the 2018 FIFA World Cup, one of nine groups used to determine which national teams from UEFA would reach the tournament in Russia. The section eventually included six sides: Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Greece, Estonia, Cyprus, and Gibraltar. Teams were initially allocated during the preliminary draw held in July 2015 in Saint Petersburg, where UEFA established the group-stage framework and match calendar for the upcoming campaign.

A notable administrative change occurred after the draw. Gibraltar became eligible to take part once it was accepted as a FIFA member in 2016, and it was subsequently placed into Group H. At the same time, UEFA managed political and security considerations connected to Kosovo’s admission by avoiding certain pairings, including keeping Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo apart in the group phase. Because Gibraltar’s inclusion increased the number of participants, the scheduling approach for the group had to be adjusted.

Group H also intersected briefly with planning for the host nation. Russia, already qualified automatically as tournament organisers, had been linked to the original five-team version of the group so that it could play friendly matches on the same international dates as Group H’s “bye” rounds. These friendlies were intended as preparation for Russia and did not influence the qualifying table. When Gibraltar was added and the group expanded to six teams, those spare dates disappeared, and the concept of coordinated friendlies was dropped.

As in other UEFA groups, each team played the others twice, once at home and once away, producing a standard double round-robin format. Results were compiled into a standings table that ranked sides primarily by points, with goal difference and other tie-breakers used when needed. The first-place team earned direct qualification to the World Cup finals. The second-place team’s route was more uncertain: runners-up were compared across groups, and the strongest of them advanced to a play-off round for the remaining European spots.

Belgium finished top of the group and secured automatic qualification. Greece ended the campaign in second position and progressed to the play-offs as one of the best runners-up, but were eliminated over two legs by Croatia, which meant Greece did not reach the finals for the first time since 2006.

The group’s matches produced a high goal total, with Belgium’s attack contributing heavily. Romelu Lukaku led the scoring charts for the group, while several other players—including Eden Hazard, Edin Džeko, and Konstantinos Mitroglou—were among the more frequent scorers. Defensive discipline also shaped squad selection: under UEFA rules, red cards and accumulated yellow cards triggered automatic suspensions, affecting availability for key fixtures and carrying over to the play-offs where applicable.

Cope is an English-language surname found in many countries, especially in Britain, Ireland, North America, and parts of the former British Empire. Like many family names, it has been carried by people active in a wide range of fields, so it often appears in biographical lists and reference works.

In politics and public service, several individuals named Cope have held office or served in government roles, including members of Parliament and officials connected with British administration. The name also appears in legal and judicial contexts through judges and other civic figures. In addition, certain Cope families have been associated with local influence and long-standing involvement in regional affairs, which is why genealogical sources sometimes discuss “Cope” as more than just a single person’s surname.

The arts provide another visible group of bearers of the name. Cope has been used by poets, musicians, actors, and visual artists, spanning different periods and styles. In literature and performance, it may be encountered both as a birth surname and as a professional name.

Science and scholarship form a further category. People named Cope have contributed to disciplines such as chemistry, medicine, anatomy, classical studies, and economic research, with some becoming well known through published work or academic posts. Sports and broadcasting also include multiple Copes, from football and cricket to motor racing and rugby, as well as commentators and media personalities.

Because the surname is shared by many unrelated individuals, reference pages often provide a “see also” section linking to similar spellings or related disambiguation entries.

Revenue can be artificially boosted when a company pushes more merchandise into its distribution network than the network can realistically sell to end customers. This tactic is commonly called channel stuffing, and it usually involves offering distributors or retailers unusually large shipments near the end of a quarter or year. On paper, those shipments may be recorded as “sales,” even though the products are still sitting in warehouses or on store shelves and may later be returned or heavily discounted.

The motivations vary. Senior management may be trying to meet earnings expectations, stabilize a stock price, or satisfy lenders’ performance requirements. In other cases, the pressure comes from within the sales organization: aggressive quotas and short reporting periods can encourage sales teams to prioritize immediate volume over sustainable demand. When incentives reward shipments rather than sell-through, the system can drift toward oversupplying the channel.

The longer-term impacts are often harmful. Excess inventory tends to boomerang back to the manufacturer through returns, buybacks, or special concessions. Holding and handling those unsold goods raises logistics costs and can clog warehouses. Production planning also becomes less reliable: factories may ramp up to support a surge in shipments, only to face a sudden lull in orders afterward, leading to overtime, idle capacity, or abrupt schedule changes.

Pricing can suffer as well. To persuade partners to take unwanted stock, companies frequently use steep discounts, extended payment terms, or marketing allowances. These incentives reduce margins and can distort market pricing. When too much product is floating around, it may leak into unauthorized resale channels, undermining official distributors and confusing customers about legitimate pricing.

Large retailers sometimes recognize the pattern and exploit it. By delaying routine purchases until a supplier’s reporting deadline, they can negotiate more favorable terms when the supplier is eager to “hit the number.” The next period may then start with minimal orders as the retailer works down inventory, perpetuating a cycle of spikes and slumps.

Because channel stuffing can mislead investors about true demand, regulators and auditors may scrutinize it, particularly when revenue recognition rules are stretched or when it accompanies other accounting concerns.

Hawton is a village and civil parish in the western part of the Metropolitan Borough of Doncaster in South Yorkshire, close to the county boundary with North Yorkshire. The parish includes the neighbouring settlements of Elden and Carrfield, and in recent decades has maintained a population of a little over four thousand residents. Its northern edge follows a small river valley, while a long-established coaching route and later main road defines much of the boundary to the west. The surrounding landscape is largely flat, with wide fields, drainage ditches, and scattered woods that reflect centuries of agricultural use.

Very little is documented about Hawton before the late 11th century, when places in this region first appeared in national surveys of landholding and taxation. At that time the community would have been small, with most households tied to farming and seasonal labour. In the medieval period, a larger neighbouring village developed religious and commercial importance, gaining a church and regular trading opportunities, while Hawton remained a quieter agricultural hamlet. Local legend connects nearby woodland to outlaw stories that circulated across Yorkshire, but firm evidence for those links is limited and tends to belong more to folklore than to record.

A small religious house was later founded close to the river, taking advantage of access to water and fertile ground. Like many minor priories, it never became wealthy or politically prominent, and its buildings were eventually removed during the suppression of monastic institutions in the 16th century. Over time, the land was absorbed into private estates, and control of the manor changed hands several times. In the 18th century a notable benefactor left money for local poor relief and assigned parts of the estate to an educational foundation, an arrangement that influenced rents, repairs, and the management of parish land for generations. A substantial manor residence was constructed during this period, symbolising the estate’s authority and providing employment for local craftsmen.

Through the 19th century Hawton continued to depend on farming, but its social life expanded. Inns and beerhouses appeared along the main road to cater for travellers and labourers, and a school and chapel were added as literacy and nonconformist worship grew in the countryside. The arrival of the railway in the mid-1800s changed the village’s connections even if it did not immediately transform its economy. A small station on a branch line allowed quicker movement of people, livestock, and produce to nearby market towns.

Early in the 20th century, proposed coal mining in the wider area encouraged speculative building. Rows of red-brick terraces were erected in anticipation of new workers, and when pits opened within travelling distance, additional services—especially a larger public house—were established. After the Second World War, further housing estates gradually filled gaps between older cottages, and several historic farm buildings and the manor house were demolished, replaced by modern developments.

Today Hawton functions mainly as a residential village for commuters travelling to Doncaster, Pontefract, and other nearby centres. It retains a small selection of amenities, typically including a shop, social club, and a couple of pubs. Much of its older architectural character has been reduced, though a small number of listed features—such as a historic pump or milestone—still provide visible links to the parish’s long rural past.

William, Willie, or Billy Dunn is a name shared by a wide range of people in public life, and it can refer to individuals in politics, sports, the military, academia, and the arts. Because the surname Dunn is common in the United Kingdom, Ireland, North America, and other English-speaking regions, lists of “William Dunn” often collect notable figures from different centuries and professions.

In politics and public service, several William Dunns have held elected office or civic leadership roles. Some were members of national legislatures in Britain or the United States, while others served in local government as mayors or municipal officials. A number of men named Sir William Dunn also appear in historical records, reflecting British titles such as baronetcies that were passed through families.

Sports is another area where the name appears frequently. Football (soccer) records include multiple players called William or Billy Dunn from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, some associated with well-known clubs in Britain. Other athletes include golfers—where “Willie Dunn” may refer to both players and course designers—as well as competitors in Olympic or international events in disciplines such as bobsleigh. In some cases, the same sport contains more than one notable Dunn, so birth years or team affiliations are used to distinguish them.

Beyond politics and sport, the name is linked to varied careers: industrialists involved in agriculture or milling, military figures recognized for wartime service, physicians connected to professional medical institutions, and academics working in fields such as international relations or biochemistry. The entertainment and cultural sphere includes performers and writers, and in Canada the name is also associated with a musician and filmmaker who engaged in activism and public debate.

Related entries often point readers to broader resources, such as pages for “Bill Dunn,” the general Dunn surname, or similarly spelled names like Donne.

In Mende religious tradition from Sierra Leone, Ngewo is regarded as the highest creator deity and ruler of the sky. Accounts describe this supreme being as the source of the world’s existence and the power that governs major forces of nature, such as weather and other events that shape life on earth. Some explanations also note that ideas about Ngewo developed through the joining of earlier divine figures: a male creator associated with the name Ngewo and an older female divinity, Leve. In this combined understanding, Leve is often treated as Ngewo’s partner, while worship centers on the single, overarching name.

Ngewo is frequently characterized as remote. Rather than being involved in everyday problems, he is seen as dwelling above and remaining beyond ordinary human reach. Even so, stories suggest that neglect has consequences. People who fail to honor the creator through prayer or tribute may be corrected or punished, not because Ngewo is constantly present, but because proper respect is viewed as maintaining balance between humans and the divine order.

Communication between Ngewo and the community is often described as indirect. Ancestor spirits, commonly called dyinyinga, function as intermediaries who can carry concerns upward and deliver guidance downward. These spirits may also require offerings, especially food, reflecting the idea that the living and the dead remain linked through ritual exchange.

Several myths explain key features of human life. One narrative tells of a time when Ngewo lived alone on earth and, seeking companionship, made animals in pairs before shaping the first man and woman. Another tale accounts for mortality: two animals were sent with opposing messages about human destiny, but the bearer of death arrived first, fixing death as part of the human condition.

TriBeCa, sometimes written as Tribeca, was an American drama anthology that premiered in 1993 on the Fox network. Developed by producer David J. Burke and made in association with TriBeCa Productions, the project also involved Robert De Niro and Jane Rosenthal in a producing capacity. Each installment told a self-contained story, using the TriBeCa area of lower Manhattan as a shared backdrop rather than following a single continuing plot. The program’s opening music was “Keep It Going,” performed by the alternative hip hop artist Me Phi Me.

The series became known for recruiting high-profile talent both in front of and behind the camera. Alongside regular performers such as Philip Bosco and Joe Morton, episodes featured a wide range of guest actors, including Eli Wallach, Kevin Spacey, Kathleen Quinlan, Carol Kane, Debbie Harry, and Danny Aiello III. Notable musicians also appeared, among them jazz legend Dizzy Gillespie. Creative duties were similarly varied, with scripts and direction handled by Burke and additional filmmakers and writers such as Hans Tobeason, John Mankiewicz, Barry Primus, Bryan Spicer, and Jeffrey Solomon.

Critical response highlighted the show’s ambition and the caliber of its participants. Laurence Fishburne earned a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series for his lead performance in the opening episode, “The Box,” where he played Martin McHenry. Even with strong reviews and award recognition, the series struggled to build an audience and was cancelled after seven episodes, concluding its only season in 1993.

The Dark Side of Nowhere is a middle-grade science fiction novel by American author Neal Shusterman. Released in 1997 by Little, Brown and Company, the book is about 256 pages long and is often recommended for readers around age twelve and older. It blends familiar school-and-family settings with unsettling mystery, using a small town to explore questions about identity and belonging.

The story centers on Jason Miller, a teenager who begins the day feeling as though something is off. The problem is not simply mood or stress; his sense of self seems to have shifted, and the world around him no longer fits the life he remembers. After a sudden tragedy involving his friend Ethan, Jason notices that people in his community behave in odd, almost staged ways. Conversations feel rehearsed, reactions seem delayed, and even those closest to him appear to be hiding information. As Jason tries to understand what has changed, he becomes increasingly suspicious of the town’s routines and the “normal” life he once wanted.

As the plot develops, Jason is pushed into a transformation that forces him to confront what the town really is and what role he has been assigned within it. The novel uses science fiction elements to raise broader ideas about conformity, the pressure to fit in, and how a desire for an exciting life can lead to unexpected consequences.

The book has been recognized on several youth reading lists and award programs, including state-level selections and honors from library and young adult literature organizations in the late 1990s and early 2000s.

Punk in Drublic is the fifth studio album by American punk band NOFX, issued in 1994 through Epitaph Records. Arriving after the group had already built a strong underground following, the record helped push 1990s skate punk into wider visibility. It keeps the band’s fast, abrasive approach, but it also adds more melodic hooks and tighter song structures than many of their earlier releases. Lyrically, the album mixes sarcasm, social commentary, and personal frustration, often delivered with humor that contrasts with the speed and intensity of the music.

The album’s title is a playful twist on the phrase “drunk in public,” hinting at recurring themes of substance use and misbehavior without presenting them in a celebratory way. Musically, the songs are built around quick tempo changes, choppy guitar rhythms, and busy drumming. Short tracks dominate the running time, giving the record a relentless pace, but several songs slow down just enough to highlight NOFX’s knack for melody.

Release and promotion for Punk in Drublic came at a moment when independent labels were gaining attention as punk and alternative rock reached larger audiences. The record benefited from extensive touring and word-of-mouth support in skate and college scenes. Over time it became one of Epitaph’s best-known releases and a frequent entry point for new listeners exploring 1990s punk.

Critical and fan reception has often focused on the album’s blend of technical playing and accessible choruses. Many listeners cite it as a benchmark for skate punk production in the mid-1990s: loud and energetic, but clearer and more balanced than many DIY recordings from the era. The album is also commonly referenced in discussions of punk’s shift toward broader popularity during the decade, even though NOFX remained outside the major-label system.

Track highlights include “Linoleum,” “Leave It Alone,” and “The Brews,” all of which became staples in live sets. The record’s lasting presence is also tied to its distinct sense of humor, which influenced later pop-punk and skate-punk bands looking to combine sharp commentary with catchy songwriting.

The lineup at the time featured Fat Mike on bass and vocals, El Hefe on guitar and trumpet, Eric Melvin on guitar, and Erik “Smelly” Sandin on drums. Together, they produced an album that captures a specific moment in punk history while remaining a widely recognized example of the genre’s sound.

The 1969 Texas A&I Javelinas football squad represented the Texas College of Arts and Industries—today Texas A&M University–Kingsville—during the 1969 NAIA season. Competing in the Lone Star Conference, the Javelinas were led by long-time head coach Gil Steinke, who was in his 16th season guiding the program. Texas A&I produced an outstanding year, finishing 11–1 overall and 6–1 in conference play. That performance earned the team a share of the Lone Star Conference title, and it capped the season by winning the NAIA national championship after a victory in the Champion Bowl. The campaign included only one defeat.

The roster drew significant recognition from conference coaches when the All–Lone Star Conference teams were announced. Fourteen Javelinas received first- or second-team selections, reflecting strength across both offense and defense. Among the first-team honorees were defensive backs Alvin Matthews and Ed Scott, along with standouts on the line and at linebacker, including Don Hynds, Curtiss Neal, Margarito Guerrero, and Robert Young. On offense, James Respondek and linemen such as Andy Browder and Ronald Fielding were also placed on the top unit. Second-team selections included quarterback Karl Douglas, running back Henry Glenn, receiver Dwight Harrison, and center Tom Domel, among others.

Several players gained attention beyond the conference level as well. Matthews and Guerrero were named to the Associated Press Little All-America second team, while Young earned third-team recognition and Scott received honorable mention. The Javelinas played their home games at Javelina Stadium in Kingsville, Texas.

The so‑called Tomb of Eve is a former burial landmark once found in Jeddah on Saudi Arabia’s Red Sea coast. Locally it was often referred to as Eve’s Grave, and popular tradition linked it to Hawwa (Eve), who in Islamic and wider Abrahamic lore is regarded as the first woman. Although no archaeological proof confirms the identification, the site became a point of curiosity for residents and travelers and, at times, a destination for visitors seeking blessing.

Descriptions of the location appear in early twentieth‑century accounts by diplomats and writers. One British consular report from 1926 provides a rare administrative reference to the monument, while other observers mention its unusual proportions. Estimates varied, but several authors described a very long, narrow tomb outline, far larger than an ordinary grave. This exaggerated scale encouraged debate: some treated it as symbolic, while others used it as evidence that the claim could not be literal.

The tomb also intersected with the city’s name and folklore. Jeddah is commonly glossed as “grandmother” in Arabic, and this meaning supported the popular idea of Eve as an ancestral figure connected to the area, even if the linguistic explanation is disputed among scholars.

Religious and political authorities eventually restricted the site. Attempts to remove or reduce the monument were reported in the late Ottoman period, and it was ultimately dismantled under Prince Faisal in 1928. Later, in 1975, remaining traces were covered with concrete to discourage devotional practices at graves, which many clerics viewed as improper. Today, the Tomb of Eve survives mainly through historical references and the continuing interest it generates in discussions of Jeddah’s heritage.

Erica Jasmin Mena (born November 8, 1987) is an American reality television figure who first built public recognition through modeling work and appearances in hip hop music videos. Over time, she expanded into television and publishing, becoming a familiar face within the Love & Hip Hop franchise.

Mena’s early career was rooted in the entertainment and fashion worlds, where she worked as a model and gained attention as a “video vixen.” This label is commonly used for women featured prominently in music videos, particularly in the hip hop and R&B genres. During this period, she appeared in videos connected to well-known recording artists, which helped her develop name recognition beyond traditional modeling.

Her profile grew further when she transitioned to reality television. She appeared on shows that followed the personal and professional lives of cast members, a format that often blends behind-the-scenes access with scripted structure. Mena became best known for her role on Love & Hip Hop: New York, the first series in a long-running franchise focused on relationships and careers within the hip hop industry. She later joined Love & Hip Hop: Atlanta and also returned to Love & Hip Hop: New York for a milestone season. In addition, she participated in VH1’s Scared Famous, a competition series that combines celebrity casting with horror-themed challenges.

Outside television, Mena has also pursued writing. She released autobiographical books that present her personal experiences and public image through a confessional style, reflecting on relationships, self-perception, and life in entertainment.

In her personal life, Mena has publicly identified as bisexual and has spoken about her Latina heritage, with Puerto Rican and Dominican family roots. She attended Newburgh Free Academy in Newburgh, New York. She is a mother of three children. Her first child, a son born in 2007, is with music video director and rapper Raul Conde, associated with Fat Joe’s Terror Squad. Mena was previously engaged to performer Bow Wow. She later became engaged to rapper and TV personality Safaree Samuels in 2018; the couple married in 2019 and welcomed a daughter in 2020 and a son in 2021. In 2021, reports indicated that Mena filed for divorce from Samuels.

Ditte Hansen (born 6 December 1970 in Copenhagen) is a Danish performer and writer recognized for combining acting with scripted comedy and satire. She is especially associated with the television series *Ditte & Louise*, which later expanded into a feature film, and with her work in Denmark’s long-running revue tradition.

Hansen grew up in Copenhagen in a difficult home environment marked by her father’s alcoholism. Episodes of instability and mistreatment left lasting effects, and she has spoken about seeking professional support at times to manage the impact of those experiences. In adulthood, she has described having a strong personal support system, including her relationship with her spouse.

Her professional training began at the Odense Theatre’s acting school, from which she graduated in 1996. Soon after, she worked at the theatre for several years, gaining stage experience that later informed her screen roles. She entered Danish film with a part in Hella Joof’s comedy-drama *Oh Happy Day*, and later became a familiar face in popular entertainment, including the annual *Cirkusrevyen*, where performers present sketches, songs, and political humor.

Alongside acting, Hansen has taken on high-profile hosting work within the Danish theatre world, including presenting the Reumert awards in 2010 and again in 2011. On television she has appeared in both dramatic and comedic formats, including a role as a forensic pathologist in the third season of *Forbrydelsen* (*The Killing*), as well as multiple characters in satirical programming on DR1.

From 2015 to 2018 she co-wrote and starred in *Ditte & Louise* with Louise Mieritz, producing two seasons and a film adaptation. In 2019, she added book publication to her credits with *Gode Kasser*.

The 2014 edition of the Campeonato Alagoano marked the 84th running of Alagoas’s main professional football championship. Matches were played from 12 January through 30 April, with Coruripe finishing the season as champions and lifting the state title for the third time in their history. At the opposite end of the table, Penedense and Comercial-AL ended the campaign in the relegation positions.

The tournament was organized in stages. In the opening phase, eight clubs competed in a home-and-away round-robin schedule. After all teams had faced each other twice, the four best-placed sides advanced to knockout rounds, and the stage winner earned a place in the following year’s Copa do Brasil.

A second phase then expanded the field, adding CRB and CSA, who had been involved in the 2014 Copa do Nordeste. Ten teams were divided into two groups, playing for spots in the decisive rounds. The leading teams from each group progressed to semifinals and a final. This stage also distributed national berths: the top teams qualified for the next Copa do Brasil and Copa do Nordeste, while the best overall performer secured a place in the 2014 Série D of the Brazilian Championship.

One notable change before kickoff was the merger involving Corinthians Alagoano and Santa Rita, which opened a promotion place for Penedense.

Benalto is a small settlement in central Alberta, Canada, administered by Red Deer County. It lies a short distance west of the Town of Sylvan Lake and is considered part of the region’s rural network of communities. For statistical reporting, Statistics Canada identifies Benalto as a “designated place,” a category used to present census data for populated areas that are not incorporated as municipalities.

Immediately beside Benalto is Kountry Meadows, a manufactured home community that is also treated as a separate designated place by Statistics Canada. While the two areas are closely connected in daily life, the official hamlet boundary for Benalto does not currently extend to include the manufactured home park.

Population figures for Benalto are reported through the national census program. In the 2016 Census, Benalto had 177 residents living in 63 of 66 private dwellings, a slight increase compared with 175 people in 2011. Census tables also provide measures such as land area and population density, which help describe how concentrated the population is across the settlement’s footprint. Updated counts and dwelling totals are released in each new census cycle, including the 2021 Census of Population.

Édouard-Montpetit station is part of the Montreal Metro system in the borough of Côte-des-Neiges–Notre-Dame-de-Grâce, Quebec. Managed by the Société de transport de Montréal (STM), it serves the Blue Line and sits near the base of Mount Royal, close to major educational and medical institutions. Because the station is built into the mountainside, it is notable for its depth and its distinctive underground cavern layout.

The station uses side platforms for trains in each direction. Passenger circulation is organized around several access points: a principal entrance along boulevard Édouard-Montpetit connects directly to the fare-paid area, while additional entrances link the station to nearby streets and to pedestrian routes leading toward the university sector. Internal corridors and stairways guide riders between the ticketing level, the platforms, and connecting passageways.

As with many stations in Montreal’s network, public art is integrated into the architecture. Decorative elements and wall treatments are placed in prominent areas such as the mezzanine and along pedestrian links, reinforcing the station’s identity and providing visual reference points for passengers. Digital information displays are also installed to provide service notices, the time of upcoming trains, and other transit announcements.

The station’s name reflects its location on Édouard-Montpetit Boulevard, a key east–west corridor that borders the campus area. It functions as an important transfer point between the metro and local bus routes, making it a practical gateway for students, staff, and visitors traveling to the Université de Montréal, nearby colleges, and hospital facilities.

The Primetime Emmy Award once included a category recognizing art direction for single-camera television series. Presented as part of the Creative Arts Emmy Awards, it honored the teams responsible for the visual look of a show’s environments, including sets, scenic treatments, and the overall design approach that supports storytelling. Over the decades, the name and scope of the prize shifted to reflect changes in television production and how the Academy grouped similar work.

In earlier years, the category appeared under broader titles that combined art direction with scenic design. Later, it was reshaped into awards that separated series and program types, such as dramatic productions versus other formats. By the late 1990s and into the 2000s, the single-camera focus became a defining feature, highlighting series that relied on carefully constructed locations and sets rather than multi-camera stage layouts.

In 2014, this award structure was retired and replaced by a set of production design categories organized by narrative format and length. The revised system distinguished between contemporary or fantasy narratives running an hour or more, half-hour narrative programs, and period narratives of one hour or longer. This change aimed to better compare similar kinds of productions, since a historical drama and a modern-day series often face very different design challenges.

Across its history and successor categories, certain programs accumulated multiple wins and frequent nominations, reflecting sustained recognition for consistent visual world-building. Notable repeat award recipients included period dramas and large-scale fantasy series known for detailed sets and distinctive environments. Other long-running shows earned numerous nominations, indicating steady excellence even when they did not win.

The category’s timeline spans from its mid-1950s origins through its discontinuation in 2013, after which production design awards continued under the updated classifications.

The Sisters of the Sorrowful Mother are a Roman Catholic congregation of Franciscan religious women that began in the late nineteenth century and became closely associated with caring for the sick and vulnerable. Established in Rome in 1883, the group developed during a period when many new religious communities were formed to address social needs created by urban poverty, migration, and limited access to medical services.

The origins of the congregation are connected to Father Francis Mary of the Cross Jordan, who was organizing what would later be known as the Society of the Divine Savior, or Salvatorians. Seeking a women’s branch to share in this mission, he invited Amalia Streitel, a German woman with experience in religious life and education, to come to Italy and help form a new community. After arriving in Rome, she received a new religious name, Mother Frances of the Cross, and began gathering women who wanted to combine prayer with practical works of mercy.

Early conditions were modest. Housing was sparse and resources were limited, yet the small community responded to immediate local needs by taking in children without guardians and providing basic care within their own living space. As the group grew, questions arose about governance and the direction of the new institute. Within a few years, the sisters and the Salvatorians separated, and the community came under diocesan oversight in Rome. At this stage they adopted a Franciscan-inspired way of life shaped by the Rule of the Third Order Regular of Saint Francis, balancing contemplative practice with active service.

To sustain themselves and fund their charitable work, the sisters pursued practical ministries. They offered nursing services in private homes and carried out duties connected with church life, including work in a sacristy at a Roman church associated with the German-speaking community. Over time, healthcare became a central focus, both as a response to social need and as a stable form of service that matched their charism.

A significant expansion occurred when Mother Frances of the Cross traveled to the United States at the request of a bishop in Kansas to assist a struggling hospital. This initiative led to additional foundations, including hospital work in the Midwest, later developments in New Jersey, and a mission presence farther south. In 1911, the congregation received formal papal approval, marking its establishment within the wider structure of the Church.

Today, the Sisters of the Sorrowful Mother continue their mission in multiple countries across Europe, the Americas, and parts of Africa and the Caribbean, with ministries that often remain linked to healthcare and pastoral service.

Karl August Theodor Lenz (12 February 1881 – 17 October 1952) was a German dramatist, lyric poet, and prose writer whose career bridged the late imperial era and the turbulent decades that followed. He was born in Bromberg, in the Prussian Province of Posen (today Bydgoszcz, Poland), and later studied literature and philosophy before turning to writing and theater administration.

Lenz published early volumes of poetry and a series of short novels that explored moral conflict, religious doubt, and social change in rapidly modernizing cities. Among his better-known titles are the novella collection Schatten am Fluss (1906) and the novel Die fremde Stunde (1912). He also wrote stage works, including the historical drama Herzogin Clara (1914) and the symbolic play Der Spiegelgarten (1920), which were staged in several German-speaking theaters.

In addition to his literary output, Lenz held influential cultural posts. During the 1920s he served as an artistic adviser at a municipal theater and later worked in radio, helping develop spoken-word programming and adaptations for early broadcasting. Like many cultural figures of his generation, he faced professional setbacks after 1933, when political pressure limited his public roles and curtailed productions of his work. After the Second World War he returned to publishing, contributing essays on theater practice and the responsibilities of writers in public life. He died in southern Germany, leaving a body of work that reflects both aesthetic experimentation and the constraints of his historical moment.

Varghese Kuriakose (14 February 1901 – 3 September 1972), often remembered locally as the “Pastor of Puthenpadi,” was a Syro-Malabar Catholic priest from Kerala who became known for combining pastoral work with community development. Serving in a largely rural region where poverty and poor access to services were common, he emphasized practical assistance alongside religious instruction. In later years, his reputation for personal discipline and public service led to the opening of an ecclesiastical inquiry into his life, a preliminary step used by the Church when evaluating a person’s virtues.

Kuriakose was born in 1901 in a farming family in the Alappuzha area to Mathew and Annamma. His early education took place in local government schools, after which he continued studies at a church-run college noted for training students for public examinations. He entered seminary formation in Thrissur, where he completed philosophy and theology and was ordained a priest in the mid-1920s. Those who knew him during training described him as methodical and attentive to the everyday concerns of ordinary families.

His first significant appointment came in the early 1930s, when he was sent to Puthenpadi, a parish spread across small hamlets with limited roads and few institutions. He prioritized building stable parish structures, but his efforts were not limited to church construction. Under his leadership, the community established a primary school that later expanded to include classes for girls, a small hostel for children without reliable caregivers, and a cooperative initiative that helped families obtain seeds and basic supplies at fair prices. He also encouraged preventive health practices and arranged periodic medical visits until a permanent dispensary could be organized.

Accounts of his ministry often highlight his habit of visiting households regardless of social background and mediating local disputes without taking sides. Supporters attribute to him several favors received through prayer, which are collected as testimonies during Church investigations. A diocesan tribunal later assembled written records, witness statements, and archival material to evaluate the consistency of these reports and the broader impact of his work. Regional media and parish publications have periodically featured programs and articles revisiting his legacy and the institutions that grew from his initiatives.

SkyRidge Aviation was a small Italian firm associated with the paragliding industry, known for producing paraglider wings and emergency reserve parachutes. It operated from the outskirts of Trento, after an earlier period in nearby Rovereto. Available records suggest the company was active by the early 2000s and ceased trading around 2009, during a period when several niche aviation brands struggled with rising certification costs and a tightening retail market.

The business was part of a broader holding structure called SkyRidge Sport Group, led by entrepreneur Carlo Venturi, which later appears to have dissolved. Day-to-day product development at SkyRidge Aviation was overseen by designer Luca Ferretti, who had previously worked with established canopy makers in the Alps and brought experience in pattern design, line layouts, and fabric selection. Although administrative functions remained in Italy, much of the sewing and assembly was carried out in a partner facility in Tunisia that had been set up specifically for technical textile work. This arrangement allowed the company to scale production while keeping development and testing close to European mountain sites.

SkyRidge offered a range intended to cover typical pilot progression. Entry-level wings emphasized predictable inflation and strong passive safety, while intermediate designs targeted efficient thermal climbing and better glide. At the top end, the company produced higher-performance wings for experienced pilots, along with a tandem model used by instructors and commercial operators. Product literature frequently highlighted durability, consistent trim speed, and careful quality control of stitching and line measurements.

In 2004 a prototype from the series, the Kestrel, was evaluated during a comparative demo week near Lake Garda. A reviewer noted particularly steady behavior in active air and a coherent feel on brake input, which helped build the brand’s visibility outside Italy. Near the end of its existence, SkyRidge focused on achieving European EN ratings across multiple sizes for one of its mid-level models, while an advanced wing was reportedly undergoing certification trials.

Competition participation was limited but measurable: several SkyRidge models appeared in international cross-country events and a handful of World Cup tasks during the decade, usually flown by independent pilots rather than factory teams. Known wing names associated with the company include Arco, Brio, Cirrus, Kestrel, Mira, Nova, Sirocco, and the dual-seat Duo.

Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul is a documentary released in 2005 and directed by German-Turkish filmmaker Fatih Akın. The film explores Istanbul through its music, using performances and street-level encounters to show how the city’s cultural identity is shaped by many communities and traditions. Rather than focusing on a single genre, it moves across styles that coexist in contemporary Istanbul, including arabesque, rock, hip-hop, electronic music, and folk-influenced sounds.

A central figure in the documentary is Alexander Hacke, a German musician known for his work with the experimental band Einstürzende Neubauten. Hacke serves as a guide and narrator, traveling through neighborhoods, clubs, rehearsal rooms, and informal gathering places. He and Akın record musicians in varied settings, emphasizing how music emerges from everyday urban life as much as from formal stages. This approach highlights the city’s layered character, where local traditions meet global influences and older forms continue to evolve alongside newer ones.

The film received international attention and was screened at the Cannes Film Festival in 2005 outside the main competition lineup. Its soundtrack reflects the documentary’s wide range of featured artists, presenting both well-known performers and more underground acts. By placing these musicians side by side, the film suggests that Istanbul’s sound cannot be reduced to a single narrative; it is built from contrasts, collaborations, and ongoing change.

Often categorized as a music documentary as well as a portrait of Istanbul, the film is also noted for its multilingual and cross-cultural perspective. It connects German and Turkish viewpoints while documenting a city that functions as a bridge between regions, histories, and musical languages.

Samsung R&D Institute India in Noida is one of Samsung Electronics’ major engineering hubs in the country, focusing largely on software for Samsung smartphones. The center takes responsibility for key parts of mobile software development and testing, supporting devices across Samsung’s portfolio. Alongside work for flagship and mass-market phones, the Noida team is known for contributing to mid-range products, including models designed to run efficiently on lighter Android variants such as Android Go. It has also been involved with several popular Samsung phone lines aimed at mainstream customers, including the M, J, and A series.

The institute began operations in the late 2000s with early work centered on regional customization and validation of multimedia features. Over time, its scope expanded to cover end-to-end development and verification activities for a broad range of handsets. As the organization scaled, it grew into a large engineering community with thousands of professionals working across multiple disciplines, from platform software to quality assurance.

Beyond product engineering, the Noida center carries out research and innovation in emerging technology areas. Teams explore topics such as artificial intelligence, the Internet of Things, next-generation connectivity including 5G, and mobile security. The institute has built a notable intellectual property portfolio, filing hundreds of patent applications in India and internationally. Collaboration with academia is also part of its approach, with joint projects and partnerships with leading Indian institutes for research, specialized training, and advanced degree programs.

The campus is located in Noida’s commercial tech district and offers on-site facilities such as food services, fitness and recreation spaces, and basic healthcare support, with metro connectivity providing access to the wider Delhi-NCR region.

Ronald Aspinall (26 October 1918 – 16 August 1999) was an English cricketer who represented Yorkshire and later worked as a first-class umpire. He was born in Almondbury, near Huddersfield in West Yorkshire, and developed a reputation as a dependable lower-order batsman and a right-arm fast-medium bowler.

Aspinall’s first-class opportunities arrived relatively late. He was 27 when he debuted for Yorkshire in 1946, in the period immediately after the Second World War when county sides were rebuilding their squads. Despite a short top-level career, he produced several performances that drew attention. One standout match came in 1947 against Northamptonshire, where he dominated with the ball across both innings and played a central role in a decisive Yorkshire win.

By 1948 he was appearing more often, taking on responsibilities at the head of the attack and sharing the new ball with fellow Yorkshire bowlers. He also featured in the celebrated match against the touring Australian side of 1948, commonly associated with Don Bradman’s unbeaten team. In that fixture, Aspinall managed the notable achievement of dismissing Bradman in the second innings, along with other key Australian players.

His final season at the highest level began impressively. In early 1949 he recorded excellent bowling figures and briefly led England’s national bowling averages, taking wickets at a very low cost. However, a serious Achilles tendon injury brought his first-class playing days to an abrupt end.

After leaving county cricket, Aspinall continued in the game through Minor Counties cricket with Durham during the 1950s. From 1960 to 1981 he served as a first-class umpire, extending his involvement in professional cricket for more than two decades. He died in Almondbury in 1999 at the age of 80.

Romano’s Macaroni Grill is a casual dining restaurant brand known for Italian-American dishes served in a sit-down setting. The chain operates dozens of locations across the United States and maintains corporate offices in Denver, Colorado. Its concept blends familiar American restaurant service with menu items inspired by Italian and broader Mediterranean cooking traditions.

The first Romano’s Macaroni Grill opened in 1988 in Leon Springs, Texas, an area that is now part of San Antonio. The restaurant was created by Philip J. Romano, a restaurateur whose name became closely associated with the brand’s identity. Over time, the original site changed hands and later ceased operations after a fire in 2021, leaving its future uncertain.

The company’s ownership history includes several major transactions. In 1989, Brinker International acquired franchise rights and expanded the concept significantly. By the mid-2000s, Brinker began evaluating strategic alternatives for its large portfolio of company-run restaurants. In 2008, a controlling share of the chain was purchased by Mac Acquisition LLC, tied to Golden Gate Capital, while Brinker retained a smaller minority stake for a period afterward. Another change occurred in 2013, when Ignite Restaurant Group bought the brand in an all-cash deal. Two years later, ownership shifted again when Redrock Partners acquired the business at a much lower reported price, reflecting the challenges many mid-market restaurant chains face as consumer preferences and competition evolve. In 2017, Romano’s Macaroni Grill entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, a process often used by restaurant companies to restructure leases and debt while continuing to operate. In 2018, the company expanded its portfolio by purchasing Sullivan’s Steakhouse.

Macaroni Grill’s menu centers on pasta, sauces, and classic Italian-American combinations. A signature offering is a build-your-own pasta option, allowing diners to select noodles, sauce styles, and add-ons such as proteins or vegetables. Meals commonly include complimentary bread served with olive oil, aligning with familiar Italian restaurant customs in the U.S. The brand has also promoted ingredient sourcing from Italy, highlighting relationships with family-run suppliers to emphasize authenticity and traceability.

Beyond dine-in service, Macaroni Grill has extended its presence into retail through packaged food products modeled on restaurant dishes. These items have been produced through a partnership with a large consumer food manufacturer, making the brand available to customers outside its restaurant locations.

Nutrition has been a recurring topic in the chain’s public profile. In the late 2000s, media coverage criticized the high calorie counts typical of many full-service restaurant meals. Later reporting noted improvements, pointing to menu revisions and leadership initiatives aimed at reducing calories in certain entrées and presenting lighter options.

Dark Days is the first full-length studio release by the American rock project Loaded. The album was put together in Seattle, Washington, during sessions that ran from late 2000 into early 2001 at Jupiter Studios. After the recording was completed, it initially appeared as an independent release in mid-2001, reaching listeners in the United States and Japan first. A wider European release followed the next year, helping the record find an audience beyond its original market.

The album’s background is closely connected to earlier songwriting efforts by frontman Duff McKagan. As the sessions took shape, he revisited several pieces that had been associated with his previous work and reworked them alongside newly written material. For the studio lineup, McKagan assembled musicians drawn from Seattle’s broader rock scene. Drummer Geoff Reading joined the project after playing in bands such as Green Apple Quick Step and New American Shame, while guitarist Dave Dederer came in with experience from The Presidents of the United States of America. Producer Martin Feveyear played a central role in shaping the sound and also contributed keyboard parts, giving certain tracks added texture beyond the core guitar-bass-drum setup.

McKagan handled bass throughout the record and also contributed additional instruments where needed. One notable detail is that he played piano on the song “Misery,” showing a willingness to broaden the album’s palette. Guitarist Mike Squires, known for work with groups including Harvey Danger and The Nevada Bachelors, was invited to add extra guitar layers, reinforcing the album’s dense, riff-driven approach.

Before release, McKagan confirmed the title Dark Days and chose to present the material under the band name Loaded rather than as a solo effort, signaling a more collaborative identity. Promotion for the album included a short run of club shows, including dates at House of Blues venues in several U.S. cities. As touring plans expanded, the lineup was adjusted to support live performances, adding players so McKagan could shift between roles onstage. Tours in the United States, Japan, and later Europe helped maintain momentum into 2002.

Years later, the album was reissued in 2008 on both CD and digital formats, with certain editions including bonus live recordings from the band’s Japan tour, offering a snapshot of how the songs evolved in concert.

Berseba is an electoral constituency located in Namibia’s ǁKaras Region, with the village of Berseba serving as its administrative centre. The area includes notable natural and populated sites, such as the Brukkaros crater and small settlements including Snyfontein, Helmeringhausen, Tses, Bethanie, and Goageb. At one point the constituency recorded about 6,659 registered voters. Census figures show steady growth over time: the population rose from 9,064 in 2001 to 10,589 in 2011.

The constituency is also linked to early resource exploration in Namibia. Diamonds were first identified in this broader area in 1898, and petroleum discoveries followed in 1929, highlighting the region’s long-standing connection to mining and prospecting activity.

Political representation has changed over successive regional elections. In 2010, SWAPO candidate Dawid Boois won the council seat with 1,225 votes, ahead of several opponents from parties such as the RDP, DTA, DP, and COD. He retained the position in 2015 after increasing his vote total to 1,774. In 2020, the seat shifted to the Landless People’s Movement when Jeremias Gooieman secured 1,822 votes, while SWAPO’s Steve Sensus Ovambo finished second with 1,127.

Parker Memorial Night is a live jazz release credited to Chicago-based multi-instrumentalist Ira Sullivan, documenting a concert performance from the early 1960s. The session was taped at a benefit-style tribute honoring alto saxophonist Charlie Parker, a central figure in the development of bebop. The recording first appeared on the Vee-Jay label as a single LP, capturing a compact set built around Parker-associated repertoire and a few well-known standards. Decades later, the album was expanded and reissued on CD, adding previously unissued selections from the same event and turning the original program into a longer snapshot of the band’s book.
