Critical discussion of the reissue has often highlighted the value of the expanded track list. Reviewers note that the additional performances broaden the view of the ensemble, moving from fast bebop heads to mid-tempo blues and ballad material. The core appeal is the spontaneity of the live setting: extended solos, audible interaction between horns and rhythm section, and the way familiar themes are reshaped through improvisation.

The repertoire centers on Charlie Parker compositions, alongside tunes by writers closely connected to modern jazz and the American songbook. The expanded edition also includes pieces associated with Dizzy Gillespie and other contemporaries, reflecting the wider bebop ecosystem rather than a narrow “greatest hits” approach.

Sullivan is featured primarily on trumpet and flugelhorn, supported by a quintet with tenor saxophone, piano, bass, and drums. The personnel underscores a typical bebop frontline and rhythm section, emphasizing tight unison themes, brisk tempos, and a harmonic language rooted in rapid chord changes and melodic variation.

In the early decades of motorized transport, lawmakers in several places adopted so-called “red flag” requirements for road vehicles. These rules were designed to reduce collisions and prevent horses and pedestrians from being startled by unfamiliar machines. At a time when roads were shared by walkers, carts, and livestock, even a slow-moving automobile or steam carriage could create panic, and governments treated it as a public safety issue that needed special regulation.

In Britain, a series of statutes known as the Locomotive Acts placed strict limits on the use of mechanically powered vehicles on public roads. The best-known measure, passed in the mid-1860s, required a small crew rather than a single driver and demanded that one person walk ahead of the vehicle to provide advance warning. That escort was expected to signal to other road users and to help manage encounters with horse-drawn traffic. The distance between the walker and the vehicle was set far enough to give riders and drivers time to react, and the warning could be given with a clearly visible flag by day or a lamp in low light. These restrictions reflected widespread concern that heavy, noisy machines would endanger the public and disrupt everyday travel.

A similar approach briefly appeared in the United States. In the 1890s, Vermont adopted a law aimed at steam-powered road vehicles, requiring a person to proceed ahead of the machine and alert those traveling with animals. Night travel brought an additional expectation: a red light or other clear signal to increase visibility. The rules generally focused on road-going vehicles and did not cover railways, which already operated under separate safety systems and dedicated rights-of-way.

Red flag provisions did not last long in most places. As engines improved and vehicles became more reliable and controllable, governments shifted toward other forms of regulation, such as speed limits, licensing, standardized lighting, and traffic enforcement. The brief era of red flag laws illustrates a transitional period in transport history, when societies were adapting legal frameworks to technologies that were rapidly changing how roads were used.

“The Novocaine Mutiny” is a fourth-season episode of the television comedy-drama *M*A*S*H*, first broadcast in early 1976. The story is framed around a formal military inquiry, using the structure of a hearing to revisit a chaotic day in the 4077th’s operating room. Rather than unfolding in a straightforward timeline, the episode relies on testimony from different characters, allowing the audience to compare competing versions of the same event and to see how personal agendas can shape “official” narratives.

The plot centers on Captain Hawkeye Pierce, who is accused of mutiny by Major Frank Burns. The accusation is serious: under military law, mutiny can carry extreme penalties, and the threat of a court-martial hangs over Hawkeye from the outset. To decide whether the case merits a full trial, a preliminary proceeding is convened, presided over by a superior officer brought in to evaluate the evidence.

Much of the background to the charge stems from a brief period when Colonel Potter is away from camp. In his absence, Burns takes on acting command and attempts to impose strict discipline. His efforts are less about operational necessity than about control, and they disrupt the unit’s usual routines. One example is a campaign against gambling, which Burns treats as a major breach of order. When a large sum of money goes missing, he launches a broad and intrusive search across the camp, refusing to accept the more mundane explanation that the money was simply lost during a card game. The investigation becomes increasingly petty and personal, creating tension among staff who are already stretched thin by the demands of the war.

During the hearing, witnesses describe the lead-up to the operating-room confrontation. Their accounts emphasize the pressures of mass casualties, limited time, and the need for careful triage and preparation before surgery. Hawkeye’s defense rests on a professional argument: he believes Burns was pushing patients into surgery without adequate pre-operative assessment, increasing the risk of preventable deaths. Burns, by contrast, portrays himself as the only one trying to keep the unit functioning under impossible conditions, casting Hawkeye as insubordinate and reckless.

The central incident is presented in sharply different ways. Burns claims he was deliberately incapacitated so that Hawkeye could seize control. Hawkeye describes a more mundane sequence in which Burns is removed from the operating room after his decisions endanger patients, and an accidental injury contributes to Burns being knocked out. The hearing officer ultimately concludes that the evidence does not justify escalating the matter to a court-martial, treating Burns’s account with skepticism.

After the proceedings, life at the 4077th returns to its familiar rhythm. The episode closes by highlighting the gap between rigid rule-making and the informal culture that keeps the unit functioning, suggesting that survival in a field hospital often depends as much on practicality and trust as on strict adherence to authority.

Antoine Wehenkel (10 February 1910 – 27 February 1992) was a Luxembourg politician with a professional background in engineering. He played a prominent role in the Luxembourg Socialist Workers’ Party (LSAP), serving as its president from 1970 to 1974. His parliamentary career began in 1951, when he entered the Chamber of Deputies, where he remained a central figure in national politics for more than two decades.

During the 1960s, Wehenkel moved from legislative work into government. In the cabinet led by Pierre Werner, he held responsibility for public finances as Minister for the Budget. He also took charge of economic policy in a period when Luxembourg was modernizing its industrial base and expanding energy planning, including in a ministry that combined national economy and energy matters. After a change in coalition in 1969 pushed the LSAP out of government, Wehenkel returned to parliamentary leadership rather than executive office.

He later became President of the Chamber of Deputies, a position that involves overseeing debates, maintaining procedural order, and representing the legislature externally. He held this post until 1974, when he left national politics. Alongside his national roles, he also served on the municipal council of Luxembourg City from 1951 to 1964.

“Never Again” is a phrase best known as a moral commitment to prevent the return of genocide and mass persecution. It is closely linked to remembrance of the Holocaust, but it has also been adopted in discussions of other atrocities and human rights crises. Over time, the words have moved beyond their historical origins and become a widely used title and theme across many kinds of media and public life.

In film and television, “Never Again” appears as the name of multiple productions from different eras. Early cinema includes silent-era shorts and features that used the title for stories unrelated to modern political meanings. Later works include an independent film released in the early 2000s, as well as episodes of popular television series. When used in episodic TV, the phrase typically signals a turning point, a personal vow, or a confrontation with past trauma, even when the plot is not directly about historical genocide.

The phrase is also common in publishing. Several nonfiction books employ it to frame accounts of the Holocaust or to argue for vigilance against hatred and state violence. Other titles apply “Never Again” to national security, justice policy, or the interpretation of political periods after major conflicts. In addition, some authors use the wording for alternate-history or speculative series, where the title suggests an attempt to rewrite outcomes or prevent catastrophic events in imagined timelines. Across these works, the phrase functions as a warning, a lesson drawn from history, or a call to collective responsibility.

Music has likewise embraced “Never Again” as an album title, an EP name, and a recurring song title. Artists across rock, metal, pop, and electronic styles have used it to express regret, resolve, protest, or recovery. Because the phrase is short and emphatic, it lends itself to lyrics about breaking destructive cycles—whether in relationships, personal behavior, or broader social conditions.

Beyond entertainment and publishing, “Never Again” appears in the names of advocacy groups and public initiatives. Organizations and campaigns using the phrase often focus on fighting racism and antisemitism, promoting human rights, or responding to contemporary threats such as political discrimination or gun violence. Related expressions—such as “Lest We Forget,” “Never Forget,” and equivalents in other languages—are often grouped with “Never Again” because they share an emphasis on memory, accountability, and prevention.

Secret House Against the World is a full-length studio release by Canadian hip hop artist Buck 65. Issued in 2005 through WEA, the record stands out for blending rap with elements drawn from indie rock, electronic music, and left-field pop. Several guest musicians and producers contribute to its sound, including members of Tortoise, as well as Gonzales, turntablist D-Styles, and songwriter Tim Rutili. Their involvement helps give the album a wider palette than a typical boom-bap production, with arrangements that shift between sparse beats, layered instrumentation, and more melodic passages.

Reviews from professional critics were broadly positive, though not unanimously so. On Metacritic, which aggregates published ratings into a single weighted score, the album landed in the low 70s from a modest set of reviews, a range generally associated with favorable reception. Some writers highlighted the variety of structures and textures across the track list, arguing that the constant changes keep the project engaging. Others focused on Buck 65’s delivery, noting that he sounds more comfortable matching his voice to rootsy or unconventional backdrops than on earlier releases. A few dissenting reviews described the album as challenging and emotionally distant, suggesting it may be best suited to listeners who enjoy experimental approaches to hip hop.

Boneland, published in 2012, is a novel by Alan Garner that continues the story begun in his earlier books set around Alderley Edge in Cheshire. The central character is Colin, once a boy in the previous tales and now an adult who keeps to himself in a small, prefabricated shelter perched in an old quarry. Although he remains close to the landscape that shaped his childhood, his life has taken a more scientific direction: he works as an academic connected with the nearby radio astronomy facilities at Jodrell Bank.

Colin’s present is defined by a striking gap in memory. He cannot recall anything from before early adolescence, which leaves large portions of his identity inaccessible, including family connections and the extraordinary events suggested by the earlier novels. To address this, he attends psychotherapy. Much of the narrative follows the slow, often uncomfortable process of recovery, showing how fragments of recollection can surface through conversation, association, and emotional pressure rather than through simple logical deduction.

Running alongside Colin’s modern story is a second thread set in deep prehistory in the same region. A solitary person living in a cave landscape sets out from a rocky chasm to seek contact and belonging. The two storylines echo each other across time, linking personal memory with the older, shared patterns of myth and place. Garner has described his interest in the motif of the “sleeping hero,” and the book also draws meaning from an ancient stone hand axe, a tool that acts as both archaeological object and symbolic bridge between eras.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Sorocaba is a Latin-rite ecclesiastical jurisdiction headquartered in Sorocaba, in the state of São Paulo, Brazil. It serves as a center of pastoral administration for parishes, clergy formation, and Catholic institutions in its territory, and it also leads an ecclesiastical province made up of neighboring dioceses.

The local church began on 4 July 1924, when Sorocaba was separated from surrounding jurisdictions and erected as the Diocese of Sorocaba. This reorganization reflected population growth and the need for more direct oversight of communities in the region. Decades later, on 29 April 1992, the diocese was elevated to the rank of metropolitan archdiocese, giving it additional responsibilities toward the dioceses placed under its province.

Leadership has passed through several bishops and archbishops. In the period as an archdiocese, the ordinary has been Archbishop Júlio Endi Akamine, S.A.C., in office since 28 December 2016, preceded by Archbishop Eduardo Benes de Sales Rodrigues (2005–2016) and Archbishop José Lambert Filho, C.S.S. (1992–2005). Earlier, as a diocese, it was governed by Bishop José Carlos de Aguirre (1924–1973), followed by Bishop José Melhado Campos (1973–1981) and then Bishop José Lambert Filho (1981–1992).

The archdiocese has also included coadjutor and auxiliary bishops who later received assignments elsewhere, and some priests from Sorocaba have been appointed bishops in other Brazilian dioceses. Its suffragan dioceses include Itapetininga, Itapeva, Jundiaí, and Registro.

A toy soldier is a small model figure designed to resemble a military soldier. While many people think of painted plastic or metal figurines used in children’s play or in collectible displays, the phrase “toy soldier” also appears as a title or theme across a range of cultural works.

In literature, the term has been used for both poetry and fiction. It can serve as a straightforward reference to the miniature figures themselves, but it is also often employed as a metaphor for duty, conformity, or the loss of individuality. Some novels and other written works use “toy soldiers” to evoke controlled behavior or to comment on war from a domestic, everyday perspective.

Film and television have adopted the phrase in multiple ways. It has been used for action stories involving hostage situations, for dramatic narratives focused on conflict and resilience, and for documentary projects exploring real events or social issues. Individual television episodes in different series have also carried “toy soldier” as an episode title, typically to suggest characters being manipulated by larger forces or placed into rigid roles.

The name is also prominent in gaming. “Toy Soldiers” has been used for action-strategy titles that blend playful miniature aesthetics with battlefield mechanics, sometimes expanding into sequels and follow-up releases. These games often treat warfare as a tabletop-like scenario, using stylized units and accessible controls while still incorporating tactical decision-making.

In music, “Toy Soldier(s)” appears as the name of performing groups as well as the title of songs spanning pop, rock, and hip-hop. Songwriters frequently use the image to explore themes such as emotional vulnerability, being controlled by someone else, or the tension between innocence and conflict.

Related titles sometimes reference similar concepts using other terms for animated figures or miniature fighters, reinforcing the enduring appeal of the toy-soldier image in entertainment and art.

Hank Jones, Ray Brown, and drummer Jimmie Smith teamed up in 1976 to record a straight-ahead jazz trio date for Concord Jazz that later appeared under the alternate title *Rockin’ in Rhythm*. Built around familiar standards, the session highlights the group’s shared sense of time and their conversational approach to melody and accompaniment. A notable feature is Jones’s decision to alternate instruments: on several tracks he moves from acoustic piano to electric piano, changing the color of the ensemble without altering its small-group format.

Critical response to the album has been mixed but generally appreciative. Reviewers often point to the trio’s tight coordination and the clarity of Jones’s phrasing, while noting that the electric piano brings a different character to his playing. Some commentary has singled out performances such as “Bags’ Groove” and “Spring Is Here” as especially effective examples of the trio’s balance between swing, restraint, and blues feeling. Other assessments have been less enthusiastic about parts of the repertoire, suggesting that the song choices are uneven compared with other releases Jones made in the same era.

The track list includes “Your Feet’s Too Big,” “My Ship,” “Alone Together,” and the Ellington-associated “Rockin’ in Rhythm,” with Jones, Brown, and Smith comprising the full personnel.

Power Machines is a Russian manufacturer of equipment for the electric power industry, formed in 2000 and based in Saint Petersburg. The company specializes in large-scale machinery used in power generation, with a product range that includes steam turbines, turbine generators, and related components. Its steam turbine designs cover high-capacity units that can be applied in conventional thermal stations as well as in nuclear energy, where reliability and long service life are critical requirements. In addition to supplying domestic projects, the firm has participated in deliveries to dozens of foreign markets, and its export activity has been especially noticeable in parts of Asia.

The modern company was assembled by bringing together several long-established enterprises and design organizations in the Russian power-engineering sector. This structure reflects the way heavy electrical machinery is typically produced: different plants focus on castings and metalworking, generator manufacturing, blade production, control and testing, and engineering services. By combining these capabilities under one corporate umbrella, the company is able to develop equipment, manufacture key assemblies, and support installation and maintenance through the full life cycle of a power unit.

Changes in ownership were an important part of its early history. After the company’s creation, a controlling stake was held through an investment vehicle linked to a major Russian industrial shareholder, while a significant minority stake belonged to an international engineering group. Several years later, the foreign partner exited by selling its shares, and the company subsequently left the Russian stock exchange. A later mandatory buyout offer to remaining minority shareholders prompted public criticism from an investor advocacy organization, followed by a regulatory review and an administrative fine related to the offer process.

Power Machines’ portfolio includes different classes of turbines and turbine-generator sets, as well as gas-turbine and combined-cycle solutions developed in-house or produced under licensing arrangements. In practical terms, this means the company can supply equipment for various plant configurations, from standalone steam turbine units to modern installations that pair gas and steam turbines to improve efficiency. Alongside manufacturing, it also provides engineering support, modernization services, and spare parts—functions that are essential for utilities operating large power stations over multiple decades.

Amar Dedić (born 18 August 2002) is a Bosnian professional footballer who operates mainly as a right-back. He is contracted to Red Bull Salzburg and has gained regular top-flight experience in Austria, including a loan spell with Wolfsberger AC. Dedić has also been involved with Bosnia and Herzegovina’s youth national teams, most notably at under-21 level.

Dedić’s development began in local football in Austria before he entered structured academy environments. He played for LUV Graz as a child and later joined Sturm Graz’s youth program in 2012, where he continued his training during his early teenage years. In 2015, he moved to the Red Bull Salzburg academy, a pathway known for promoting young players into professional football through its affiliated clubs.

His transition to the senior game started in 2019, when he signed his first professional terms with Salzburg. He then featured for FC Liefering, Salzburg’s feeder team competing in Austria’s second tier, which is commonly used to provide competitive minutes to emerging talents. Dedić made his senior debut in July 2019 and scored his first goal at professional level the following summer. His progress led to an extension of his Salzburg contract and opportunities in cup competition with the first team.

To accelerate his experience at the highest domestic level, Salzburg arranged a season-long loan to Wolfsberger AC in 2021. The move allowed him to play more consistently in the Austrian Bundesliga and continue his development in a demanding tactical environment.

Internationally, Dedić has represented Bosnia and Herzegovina across several youth categories and has worn the captain’s armband at under-17 level, reflecting his status within his age group.

Jeremiah Antonio Lewis (March 2, 1987 – August 14, 2019), professionally known as J-Lex, was an American hip-hop artist associated with the Southern rap scene. He gained his widest recognition with the 2016 track “Run It Up,” which entered the Billboard Hot 100 at number 92. Lewis was killed in a shooting in 2019.

Lewis was born in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and spent much of his childhood in the region before relocating to Dallas as a teenager. He frequently cited local bounce music along with mainstream rap influences such as OutKast, Lil Wayne, and The Notorious B.I.G. as shaping his approach to rhythm and storytelling. Friends and collaborators described him as focused on melodic hooks and concise, street-level narratives.

Using the name J-Lex, he began releasing mixtapes online in the early 2010s and built a following through regional radio play and live shows. His growing profile led to attention from established Southern performers and, eventually, a distribution agreement with a major label imprint in 2016. That same year, “Run It Up” became his breakthrough single, earning streaming traction and modest chart success. Music publications highlighted him as an emerging voice, and he made televised appearances performing the song to promote an accompanying mixtape.

On August 14, 2019, Lewis was shot outside a late-night diner in Baton Rouge and died at the scene at age 32. His death prompted tributes from fellow musicians and renewed interest in his recorded work.

The Hapa–Bilaspur Superfast Express is a long-distance passenger train in India that links Hapa in Gujarat with Bilaspur Junction in Chhattisgarh. It is operated by the Western Railway and runs once a week in each direction under train numbers 22939 and 22940.

In terms of performance, the service covers a distance of about 1,692 kilometres. The Hapa to Bilaspur journey typically takes just over 30 hours, with an average speed close to the mid-50 km/h range. The return trip from Bilaspur to Hapa is of similar duration, with minor differences due to operational factors and scheduled stops.

The train uses conventional ICF coaches designed for a maximum speed of around 110 km/h. Its rake generally includes a mix of air-conditioned and non-air-conditioned accommodation, such as AC 2-tier and AC 3-tier coaches, sleeper class coaches, and general unreserved coaches. A combined seating-and-luggage coach arrangement is also provided to handle parcels and passenger baggage.

Traction changes along the route are a notable operational feature. A diesel locomotive typically hauls the train from Hapa to Ahmedabad. Beyond Ahmedabad, an electric locomotive takes over for the remaining run to Bilaspur, with the same pattern followed in the opposite direction.

The rake is also used for other services when not assigned to this train, helping optimize coach utilization across the network.

Stampede is a black-and-white American Western released in 1949 under the direction of Lesley Selander. The film features Rod Cameron, Gale Storm, Johnny Mack Brown, and Don Castle in leading roles, with a supporting cast that includes Steve Clark, Donald Curtis, and John Miljan. Set in Arizona ranch country, the story revolves around land, water rights, and the uneasy arrival of new settlers.

The central characters are brothers Mike and Tim McCall, owners of a sizable cattle operation. To profit from unused acreage, they sell part of their range to families hoping to start farms. However, once the newcomers reach the property, they discover that the promised land lacks reliable water. The McCall ranch has blocked the local river with a dam, effectively keeping control of the area’s main supply.

John Dawson, one of the settlers, turns to the county sheriff, Aaron Ball, seeking help. The sheriff’s response is cautious and limited, reflecting the power the ranchers hold and the difficulty of enforcing a fair settlement. As tensions increase, Tim McCall grows closer to Dawson’s daughter, Connie, adding a personal conflict to the larger dispute.

With legal options failing, some settlers consider direct action, including sabotaging the dam. Retaliation threatens to escalate into violence, with plans aimed at driving the McCall herd into a destructive stampede. Like many Westerns of its era, the film uses romance and confrontation to explore authority, resources, and frontier justice.

WKLF (1260 AM) is an AM radio station that airs a soft oldies music lineup by relaying programming from its sister outlet, WBRI, based in a nearby regional hub. Licensed to the town of Fairview, New York, the station targets listeners across the Riverbend area and surrounding rural communities. The facility is operated by Northfield Media Group, which also owns several signals in the region.

### Early years on 1260 AM
The 1260 frequency first became a local voice in 1961, when it signed on as WFRV with a general-interest, middle-of-the-road sound that mixed popular music, community announcements, and regular news updates. For a period, the station’s offices were housed in a downtown hotel, a common arrangement for smaller-market broadcasters that relied on central locations and walk-in access for local advertisers.

In 1967, the station adopted the call letters WLBK, reflecting new ownership and a desire to align with a larger-market station the owners admired. Like many AM outlets at the time, 1260 AM operated with a “daytimer” authorization. That meant broadcasts were limited to daylight hours to prevent interference with distant stations that could travel farther at night due to changes in the atmosphere. Each evening the transmitter went silent and resumed the next morning.

Programming shifted with audience trends. By 1973 the station moved toward a Top 40 approach, emphasizing current hits and upbeat presentation. As FM radio gained dominance for music in the late 1970s, WLBK gradually leaned into adult contemporary, keeping a broader playlist and a calmer on-air style.

### The modern station era
Following a frequency shuffle within the local market, 1260 AM went dark in 1983 and remained off the air for several years. Service returned in 1989 as WKLF, initially launching with country music and local sports coverage. In the late 1990s the station experimented with different identities, including a period when it mirrored an FM partner carrying an adult standards format. When that FM outlet later adjusted its music strategy, WKLF continued with older-leaning programming to serve longtime AM listeners.

A technical rebuild in 2012 temporarily took the station off the air while transmission equipment and an aging tower system were replaced. The upgraded facilities improved reception in outlying parts of the county and reduced interference complaints.

In 2013, WKLF switched from music to a national sports network, reflecting industry-wide interest in live events and talk programming on AM. That run lasted several years. In 2019, the station changed direction again, ending sports to begin a full-time simulcast of WBRI’s soft oldies service, bringing familiar classics and a steady presentation back to 1260 AM.

Euseby Cleaver (1745–1819) was an Anglican churchman whose career linked England’s academic world with senior leadership in the Church of Ireland. He served first as Bishop of Ferns and Leighlin from 1789 to 1809 and later as Archbishop of Dublin from 1809 until his death, although his final years in office were affected by reports of serious illness.

Cleaver was born in Buckinghamshire into a clerical family. His father, the Reverend William Cleaver, operated a school at Twyford, and this background helped shape his early education. Cleaver attended Westminster School before entering Christ Church, Oxford. There he progressed through several degrees, beginning with a Bachelor of Arts in the late 1760s and later completing advanced theological qualifications that marked him as a well-trained candidate for higher church responsibilities.

Before his move to Ireland, he held parish appointments in England. In the 1770s he became rector at Spofforth in North Yorkshire. Later, with the support of an influential patron connected to his work as a tutor, he received additional livings in West Sussex, including Tillington and Petworth. Such appointments were common at the time and often depended on networks of education and patronage.

Cleaver’s episcopal career included a short period as Bishop of Cork and Ross, followed by his transfer to Ferns and Leighlin. Political unrest in Ireland deeply affected him: during the rebellion of 1798, his residence in Ferns was attacked, and he temporarily sought safety in Wales, within the ecclesiastical sphere of his brother, also a bishop.

He married Catherine Wynne of County Sligo, and they had several children. Through his daughter Caroline’s marriage to Admiral James William King, Cleaver became the grandfather of Catherine Pennefather, later known for evangelical work. Cleaver was also associated with sympathy toward the Irish language, an interest not universal among senior clergy of his era.

Araucaria humboldtensis, sometimes called Humboldt’s araucaria, is a conifer belonging to the Araucariaceae family. It occurs naturally only in New Caledonia, where it is considered threatened because its remaining stands are small and widely separated. Many individuals grow in isolation rather than in continuous forests, which can limit pollination and reduce the chance that seedlings establish successfully.

This species is strongly tied to ultramafic substrates, especially serpentine-derived soils that often contain elevated concentrations of metals such as nickel and magnesium. Because these metal-rich landscapes are also targeted for extraction, habitat disturbance from mining and associated road building has been an important driver of population decline. Fire, invasive plants, and erosion on exposed slopes can further hinder regeneration after disturbance.

Mature trees can reach roughly 25–35 meters tall. The trunk is typically straight, bearing tiers of evenly spaced branches that radiate outward and then angle upward toward the tips. This architecture creates a striking, layered silhouette. Like other araucarias, it is monoecious: pollen cones and seed cones form on the same tree but in different parts of the crown. Seed cones develop slowly, remaining attached for multiple seasons until the large seeds are fully mature.

Growth is generally slow, and young plants may take years to become established, particularly on thin, rocky soils. However, the species can tolerate strong winds and periodic dry spells once rooted. Because of its symmetrical form and evergreen foliage, it has also been planted in cultivation as a decorative tree in suitable climates.

Pakistan’s Parliament has maintained a dedicated body to keep the Kashmir dispute on the national agenda and to project Pakistan’s stance in external forums. Commonly referred to as the Parliamentary Special Committee on Kashmir, it is largely made up of experienced members from both houses: the National Assembly and the Senate. Beyond highlighting developments in Kashmir, the committee is also meant to coordinate positions among major political parties so that the issue is presented with continuity rather than shifting with each change of government.

During the 1990s, separate parliamentary committees were constituted at different times to pursue these aims. These panels varied in size and composition, reflecting political circumstances and parliamentary strength in each period. Leadership was typically given to a senior figure with cross-party standing, which helped the committee engage other parties and represent Parliament in public diplomacy. Over the years, notable politicians have chaired these committees, and the post has been treated as significant within Pakistan’s institutional framework.

When parliamentary activity was limited, a parallel arrangement was also used. Under President Pervez Musharraf, a National Kashmir Committee was created to sustain policy attention and public outreach. This reflected the view that Kashmir required ongoing coordination even when the legislature was not fully functioning.

In later years, a larger committee structure was formed with representation from both chambers and, at times, participation by serving ministers, indicating the overlap between parliamentary advocacy and executive policy. The chairperson has generally been accorded the rank and protocol of a federal minister. In recent times, Shehryar Khan Afridi has served as the committee’s chairman.

Alain Gautier, born on 8 May 1962 in Lorient, is a French sailor recognized for his career in offshore racing. He became widely known after winning the 1992–1993 edition of the Vendée Globe, the solo, non-stop race around the world. This victory placed him among the leading figures of French ocean sailing during a period when the sport was rapidly professionalizing.

Beyond competition, Gautier has played a significant role in team preparation and technical support. In 1989 he created Lanic Sport Development, a structure focused on coaching, logistics, and performance work for offshore projects. Through this organization he has been involved in the development of several campaigns, including providing support to sailors such as Ellen MacArthur in the late 1990s and Isabelle Joschke decades later. His work reflects a broader trend in modern offshore racing, where shore-based expertise—weather analysis, boat optimization, and project management—has become almost as important as time spent at sea.

Gautier also explored the America’s Cup environment. Together with Bertrand Pacé, he helped lead the Aleph Challenge aimed at entering the 34th America’s Cup in 2013. Although the project did not secure sufficient funding to continue, the team did take part in preliminary circuits using one-design AC45 catamarans before eventually stepping back.

Over the years, Gautier’s results across major events have included stage wins and podium finishes in races such as the Solitaire du Figaro, the BOC Challenge, Route du Rhum, and Transat AG2R, as well as involvement in multihull grand prix competition. His career illustrates both the athletic demands of solo ocean racing and the long-term importance of building sustainable support structures around high-level sailing projects.

Michael Hartley (born 14 February 1972) is a former Canadian track and field jumper best known for his long jump, with additional experience in the high jump and triple jump. Raised in Toronto, he developed as a versatile collegiate athlete and later represented Canada at several major international competitions during the 1990s and early 2000s.

Hartley built much of his reputation in university athletics, earning repeated all-conference and All-American recognition. While studying in the United States, he became noted for competing in multiple jumping disciplines within the same championship season, a demanding combination that requires speed, technical precision, and event-specific strength. His collegiate career included a national title in the long jump and consistent top finishes at NCAA-level meets.

Internationally, Hartley competed for Canada at global events such as the World Championships and appeared at two Summer Olympic Games. He also participated in multi-sport meets including the Commonwealth Games and Pan American Games, where his placements reflected steady competitiveness against deep international fields. Although he did not regularly medal at the senior global level, he was regarded as a reliable team member and a frequent finalist.

Across his career, Hartley’s best performances came in the late 1990s. His personal records included an outdoor long jump of 8.20 metres, a triple jump of 16.70 metres, and a high jump clearance of 2.25 metres, all achieved at major meets in North America. After retiring from competition, he remained connected to athletics through coaching and athlete development initiatives.

Nepal’s Second Constituent Assembly was a single-chamber national body created to complete the constitution-writing process after the earlier assembly could not deliver a final document. Voters chose its members in the 2013 Constituent Assembly election, with the new body beginning work in early 2014. Its central mandate was to prepare and approve a constitution, while also acting as the country’s lawmaking forum during a politically transitional period. Once Nepal’s constitution was adopted in 2015, the same institution continued its functions as the Legislature-Parliament. Its term concluded in October 2017, shortly before a new parliamentary system took effect through subsequent elections.

At the start of the assembly’s life, procedural steps focused on setting leadership and getting lawmakers formally sworn in so regular business could begin. The first sitting was chaired by the senior-most member, a common parliamentary practice intended to provide a neutral presiding figure until permanent leadership arrangements are settled. In the opening days, hundreds of elected representatives took their oaths, marking the formal start of the assembly’s authority. Major political forces publicly committed themselves to a rapid constitutional timetable, presenting constitution-making as a national priority and a test of political cooperation. The membership was also notable for high turnover, with many representatives serving for the first time, which influenced both expectations and the pace of internal organization.

Forming a government was another immediate challenge. Nepal’s interim constitutional framework encouraged parties to seek broad agreement when selecting a prime minister and assembling a cabinet. The president played a facilitating role by urging parties to choose a head of government within a set period. Negotiations then unfolded among leading parties, with discussions focused on whether to create a consensus-based administration or proceed with a majority government if full participation proved impossible. Agreements were explored on issues such as power-sharing, timelines for local elections, and a one-year goal for constitution completion. While some parties supported a government led by the largest party, others preferred to remain outside the cabinet, arguing that opposition was necessary for oversight or that key political conditions had not been met. When all-party consensus could not be achieved, the leading parties shifted toward building a majority coalition under the relevant constitutional provisions.

The assembly’s work was structured through a committee system designed to divide specialized tasks and provide detailed scrutiny of policy and administration. Committees covered areas such as state administration, public spending oversight, legislation and legal reform, governance monitoring, environmental protection, international relations and labor, and sectoral issues like finance, agriculture, development, industry, and social welfare. Additional mechanisms, including hearings and special committees, supported appointments and oversight. Together, these structures helped the assembly function not only as a constitution-writing body but also as a working parliament during a crucial period in Nepal’s institutional transition.

William T. Harris (February 3, 1844 – November 22, 1912) was a Union Army soldier who served in the 122nd Illinois Volunteer Infantry during the American Civil War. He enlisted in the summer of 1862 and was assigned as a private to Company D, a unit raised largely from central Illinois communities. Like many volunteers, Harris spent much of his service on garrison duty and in field operations as Union forces pushed deeper into the Gulf region late in the war.

Harris is best remembered for actions recognized with the Medal of Honor. During the Battle of Fort Blakely in Alabama on April 9, 1865, he took part in the assault on Confederate defenses and was credited with seizing an enemy flag under fire. Capturing a battle flag had both symbolic and practical importance: it could weaken an opponent’s morale, disrupt command signaling, and serve as clear evidence of a position being overrun. A number of medals were issued for similar acts at Fort Blakely, reflecting the intensity of the fighting and the prominence of the objective.

After the war, Harris was discharged in mid-1865. He later settled in Kansas, where he died in 1912 and was buried in a local cemetery.

David W. Blight (born 1949) is an American historian and writer known for his work on the Civil War era, the struggle over national memory, and the history of slavery and emancipation. His scholarship has helped shape how general readers and students understand the long aftermath of the war, especially the ways Americans debated what the conflict meant and how it should be remembered.

Blight was born in Flint, Michigan, and grew up in a working-class family. He completed undergraduate study at Michigan State University, then pursued graduate training in history at the University of Wisconsin–Madison, where he earned his doctorate. After teaching appointments early in his career, he joined Yale University, where he became a professor of American history and developed courses on the Civil War and Reconstruction. In addition to classroom teaching, he has often contributed to public history through lectures, interviews, and documentary projects, aiming to connect academic research to broader civic conversations.

A central theme in Blight’s work is the idea that historical events do not end when the fighting stops; instead, societies continue to contest their meaning for generations. He is particularly associated with the study of “memory,” a field that examines how monuments, anniversaries, schoolbooks, and political speeches shape public understanding of the past. Blight has argued that reconciliation between white Northerners and white Southerners after the Civil War often came at the expense of Black rights and a frank reckoning with slavery’s legacy. This approach links political history to cultural history, showing how narratives about heroism and unity can obscure the experiences of formerly enslaved people.

Among his most widely discussed books is *Race and Reunion: The Civil War in American Memory* (2001), which traces competing postwar interpretations of the conflict and explains how certain stories became dominant in national culture. The book received major recognition, including the Bancroft Prize. Blight has also written *Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom* (2018), a large-scale biography that draws on decades of research into abolitionist politics, Black intellectual life, and the changing meaning of citizenship in the nineteenth century. That biography won the Pulitzer Prize for History and was praised for presenting Douglass as both a moral critic and a strategic political actor.

Blight’s published work includes edited volumes and essay collections as well, reflecting his interest in bringing primary sources and scholarly debates to a wider audience. Across his career, he has remained focused on how the United States narrates its own past—and how those narratives influence contemporary struggles over race, rights, and national identity.

Martín Gabriel Soria (born 7 August 1979 in Rosario, Argentina) is an Argentine tango dancer and instructor known for combining stage experience with detailed teaching. He began studying movement as a child, first through local folk dances and later through tango, which became his main focus during adolescence. By his late teens he was already performing in theater productions in Buenos Aires, where he gained practical experience in choreography, musical interpretation, and partner work.

Soria’s professional visibility grew after appearing as a featured dancer in a late-1990s film project centered on Argentine dance culture. He later worked for several years as an assistant to a prominent tango director, an apprenticeship that shaped his view of tango as a disciplined performing art with a distinct vocabulary rather than only a social dance. Since 2001 he has partnered with dancer and teacher Lucía Ferrer; together they have presented workshops and performances at international tango events.

Their touring schedule has taken them across Europe, North America, and parts of Asia, with frequent invitations to festivals and academies that emphasize both technique and musicality. In 2008 Soria received an honorary recognition from a Buenos Aires tango institution for his contributions as a traveling educator. Along with Ferrer, he developed a stage piece based on the music of Astor Piazzolla and collaborated with other contemporary tango artists on a production that explored modern interpretations of traditional steps.

He has also been interviewed for a documentary about tango pedagogy and performance practice. In recent years, Soria has been based in Berlin, where he teaches regular classes and seminars. In 2012 he and Ferrer helped establish an online program designed to make structured tango training accessible to students worldwide.

Riverside Trader was one of a small group of British cargo steamers operated by a regional shipping firm that ran regular freight routes between western England and ports in eastern Canada and the United States during the interwar years. Launched soon after the First World War, ships of this type helped rebuild commercial links by carrying mixed cargoes such as manufactured goods, timber, grain, and general stores.

The vessel was constructed in 1921 at a shipyard on the River Avon. Like many merchant ships of the period, she had a steel hull and was powered by a triple-expansion steam engine. This reliable machinery drove a single propeller and provided a modest service speed of about 10 knots, which suited scheduled cargo work rather than fast passenger traffic. The layout typically included several holds, a central engine room, and deck cranes or derricks for loading in ports without modern facilities.

In peacetime, Riverside Trader followed established Atlantic lanes and worked as part of a wider fleet that connected provincial British ports with North American markets. When the Second World War began, merchant shipping was quickly drawn into the conflict. The ship was requisitioned for wartime service, sailed under blackout conditions, and was fitted with basic defensive equipment. After sustaining minor damage during an air raid while berthed in 1941, she returned to duty following repairs.

By 1943, the Battle of the Atlantic had intensified, and slow cargo steamers increasingly traveled in escorted convoys to reduce losses. In early May that year, Riverside Trader joined an outward-bound convoy heading toward Newfoundland. During a night attack by German submarines, she was struck by a torpedo and sank in heavy seas. Several crew members were lost, while survivors were recovered by an escort vessel and later landed safely in St. John’s.
